div.p: As it is Performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
LONDON, Printed for W. JOHNSTON in Ludgate-ſtreet; J. DODSLEY in Pall-Mall; and T. DAVIES in Ruſſel-ſtreet. MDCCLXV.
TO HER GRACE THE DUCHESS OF BEDFORD THIS PIECE IS MOST HUMBLY INSCRIBED, BY HER GRACE'S MUCH OBLIGED, MOST GRATEFUL, AND OBEDIENT SERVANT,

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE hint of this Piece was taken from one of the Contes Moraux of Marmontel, ſtiled L'Hereux Divorce. The foible ridiculed in the tale is, perhaps, the only one imputed to our ſex which has never yet been expoſed by a theatrical repreſentation. It is a ſimplicity, not a coquetry; it is the error of a delicate and elevated mind, unacquainted with the manners of real life, or the general frame of the human heart.

The novel was too barren of incident to furniſh out an entertainment for the ſtage, which obliged me to contrive an intire under-plot, and introduce ſeveral new characters into the Comedy, which I ſhall not take up the reader's time to point out here; and ſubmit this performance to the candor and clemency of the public, after having, perhaps, too adventurouſly hazarded their criticiſm and cenſure.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.stage: Enter, at oppoſite doors, Serjeants POMPOUS and PLACID, pleaders in the court of Parnaſſus: They look round the houſe.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: HERE's a full court.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Come, brother, let's begin.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: The judges, are they ſeated?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Juſt gone in.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: The jury?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Special; freeholders in wit.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: E comitatû lit'rator'm, the pit.
So far, ſo well. Come, now let's ſee the pannel:
No pack'd one for the job, I hope, no canaille.
sp.stage: Placid takes out a paper, and reads.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: The foreman, Silence.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Senſe, Spirit, Taſte;
And by their fellows you may gueſs the reſt,
Including Mercy, which, tho' laſt, not leaſt.
Good men and true, all ſworn before Apollo,
To hear the truth, and nought but juſtice follow.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: Know then, my lords, and gentlemen o'th' jury,
We've found a bill i'th' records of old Drury,
In which the culprit's charg'd, in this here cauſe,
With rankeſt treaſon againſt nature's laws,
By introducing 'mong the ſcenes of life,
A thing unheard-of, a Platonic Wife;
Fair, blooming, and 'bout twenty-five—no more—
I thought, at leaſt, ſhe had been ſixty-four!
Here reſts my plea: In order to make good
The rights and properties of fleſh and blood,
For evidence upon yourſelves I call,
And ſet the cauſe on this, to ſtand or fall,
Have ye now one Platonic Wife among ye all?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: My lords and gentlemen, attend a while,
Nor let too ſpecious words your ſenſe beguile.
My brother's ſomewhat warm; but, entre nous,
Might not Platonic Wives ſuit ſome of you?
Men fond of hunting, drinking, or debate,
Would they repine at a Platonic mate?
Their hearts are aliened from domeſtic life,
And hounds, or wine, or party, are a wife.
Beſides, he argues from the common laws,
But I in equity defend the cauſe;
Plead, women are not bound by Nature's rules,
Nor are their morals borrow'd from the ſchools:
How many ſacrifice their youthful charms
To an old, wealthy huſband's feeble arms!
Or yield to titles what they owe to merit,
Wretched themſelves, that children may inherit!
Theſe ſure are Platoniſts, who thus forego
Nature's true joys for wealth, or rank, or ſhew!
Our heroine, tho' ſhe differs wide from theſe,
Has but refin'd upon the ſame diſeaſe.
Our auth'reſs too, perhaps, to aid her cauſe,
May boaſt herſelf the great ſublime ſhe draws.
By reaſon's ſtandard, then, you judge amiſs
Of thoſe whoſe legiſlator is caprice:
I therefore crave exception for this night,
And plead the privilege of Female-right.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: Well, Sirs, the caſe is ſtated, proofs at hand,
All ready here in court, at your command.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Liſten with candor; as ſhe merits, treat her.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: Freely condemn,

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Or honourably acquit her.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: LUCY, maid to Emilia, Mrs. HIPPISLY.
BETTY, maid to Clarinda, Mrs. LEE.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Drawing-Room. Lady FANSHAW and CLARINDA diſcovered.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I REJOICE to find that your ladyſhip's good nature is as much delighted as mine, at lady Frankland's happy eſcape from the galling chain of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Why really, Clarinda, I look upon it, that next to the felicity of widowhood is that of being ſeparated. However, there are, my dear, ſome material differences: While the tyrant lives to whom we have been bound, we never can forget we have been ſlaves. There are, beſides, ſome other diſagreeable circumſtances which attend a ſeparation, from which, thank Heaven, my ſtate is free.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: You mean, I ſuppoſe, the power a huſband has of withdrawing alimony, in caſe of indiſcretion, and forcing the wretched wife upon certain moyens de vivre, whether ſhe will or no.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: True. Now you know that ſince that Gothic ſtatute of the Black-Ram, in the North-weſt Riding, has been aboliſhed, we widows may chuſe what hobby-horſe we pleaſe; ſometimes, for variety, perhaps an aſs; but oh! defend me from a mule, 'tis ſo vaſtly like a huſband.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Oh! the happieſt ſimile in the world: for, on my conſcience, they ſeem equally to be deviations from the laws of nature. However, when broke, from reſtiveneſs, they are the beſt pack-ſaddle amblers in the world.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: But now, my dear Clarinda, that we have got this pretty little bird out of its cage, what think you will it do with its freedom? 'Tis vaſtly wild, and will, I imagine, take flight to ſome Arcadian grove, and ſit and ſing alone.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
O no; that muſt not be: it would diſgrace our generalſhip. She dies for ſentimental paſſion; and when once her romance is known, I warrant we ſhall be able to ſupply her with pretenders enough, who may aſſume by turns, the crook and ſcrip, the helmet and the lance, to hold her in play. Nay, piqued as ſhe was at what ſhe ſtiled lord Frankland's indifference toward her, I am perſuaded that if one tender tear had but gliſtened in his eye, at the inſtant of their ſeparation, ſhe would have ſunk into his arms, and like the plaintive turtle, have
moaned and cooed away the remainder of her life, in true conjugal inſipidity.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I am ſurprized this did not happen, for I am quite of opinion that lord Frankland loves her.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: He certainly does; but then he did not deify her. My lord knows himſelf to be a mere mortal man, and has not the preſumption of lxion, to cope with goddeſſes.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: He once, I think, admired you, Clarinda; it was thought you liked him too: how happened you to eſcape the nooſe?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Platonics, lady Fanſhaw, all Platonics. So vulgar a notion as matrimony, never once, I believe, entered either of our heads; and I dare ſwear he wiſhes now, that he had never changed his mind ſince in that article.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: 'Tis poſſible he may; and that at length, tired with the pettiſhneſs of a ſpoiled child, he may return and throw his devoirs again at the feet of one who will at leaſt treat him like a reaſonable creature.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I dare not indulge the hope; but I ſhall endeavour though, to lay every obſtacle in the way to their re-union. Lady Frankland is young and handſome; ſhe may be virtuous too; but how long that ſame fortreſs, called Chaſtity, will hold out when beſieged by flattery, the love of which is her chief foible, I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Why juſt as long, Clarinda, as any other fortreſs, where the governor loves money, and the beſiegers come up to his price. But among thoſe who either are, or pretend to be, her adorers, I cannot yet perceive that ſhe has ſhewn the ſmalleſt preference; and I really believe that ſhe admires Alexander, Cyrus, or Orondates, more than any man alive.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Perhaps ſhe may think ſo too; but be aſſured, lady Fanſhaw, that any perſon who ardently deſires to inſpire a romantic paſſion is not unſuſceptible of a natural one; and when that takes place, ſhe will e'en act an old proverb, and accept of the living dog, inſtead of the dead lion.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: But come, my dear Clarinda, and let us attend the levee of this eccentric comet, which, like other blazing ſtars, perhaps glitters but to fall.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A dreſſing-room. Lord FRANKLAND gazing on a female picture.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Thou beauteous ſhade of that angelic form, whoſe wild caprices have deſtroyed my peace, I could for ever gaze upon thee! As lord Townly ſays, "Why did I marry?" Oh! rather ſay, Why did I quit my charge, deputed as I was her virtue's guard?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Good morning to your lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Good morrow, Charles.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I grieve to find your lordſhip's contemplations ſtill fixed upon that gloomy ſubject.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: And wherefore ſhould they not? Why gloomy, Charles? Look with what innocence ſhe ſmiles upon me! and ſure that painting is the portrait of her heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I have not the leaſt doubt of lady Frankland's innocence or virtue; but ſurely, my lord, it were a childiſh folly to caſt our play-thing from us, then ſit and mourn its loſs.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I have not done ſo, Charles: I have thrown a diamond in a flaming furnace; if it eſcape without a crack or flaw, its value then is proved.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Ay, if it does, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Why ſhould you doubt it, Charles? I know her merits, and her foibles too—her real love of virtue, with her fond wiſhes to inſpire a vain, romantic paſſion.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: And can you think, my lord, that to obtain ſo fair, ſo rich a prize, there are not men who will aſſume the ſemblance of a more romantic paſſion, than even your lordſhip feels?

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Perdition's in that thought! Oh, Charles, had I but ſhewn the thouſandth part of that fond love I feel for lady Frankland, this fatal ſeparation ne'er had happened.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: I have been, my lord, to inquire lady Frankland's health, and was anſwered by her woman that her ladyſhip had ſat up late, reading a new romance; that ſhe had wept much, and ſlept little, but was in tolerable health this morning.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: May each new morn, freſh from its downy wings, ſhed health and happineſs around her! Order my chariot, Ambroſe, and ſee that all things are got ready for my departure this morning. I ſhall go to Belle-veüe, for how long I know not. Perhaps air, exerciſe, and change of objects, may throw off this ſad weight.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Shall I accompany your lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: No, Charles; you ſeem to have ſome doubts of lady Frankland's conduct: I would have you, therefore, be a witneſs to it; for my part I have none. Your intimacy with Emilia, who now lives with my wife, will furniſh you with ſufficient opportunities to know every ſtep ſhe takes, and I ſhall thank you with true gratitude, to deal with ſtricteſt juſtice.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Ay, toward myſelf I will. This poor, weak man has parted from his wife, for wiſhing he ſhould love her, and now ſits pining at yon baby-face, and longs to have the limbs to it again. But ſhould that happen, he may perhaps get others, which muſt contract and cripple mine. Counſellor Frankland, with four hundred pounds a-year, and that dipt up to the chin too, is but a poor lover ſor Emilia, with
fifteen hundred; but the ſame man, heir to lord Frankland's rank and fortune, ſounds well enough. Therefore the caſe ſtands thus: my bird is almoſt caught, and ſhall I looſe the ſtring, and let it fly, to lure his to the neſt again, where it may ſit and breed, while I am whiſtled down the wind to prey at fortune?

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: An anti-chamber in Lady Frankland's houſe.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Nicodumpus, Nicodumpus, maka de hot vater for my lady breakfaſt. Vite, Nicodumpus.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: What can ſhe mean now?

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Why you no ſtir, Nicodumpus? my lady up this half-an-hour, and has no gota her tea. In my countré de valet de chambre hava de caffé, de gateau, ready again de lady ſit up in her bed; they carry it to her ruelle, they clap it upon her lap, they tell her de news of de ville, of de compagne, of every ting in de vorld; they maka her laugh, and put her in de bon humeur for de whole day. O, de Engliſh ſerviteurs ſont de mere bétes!

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p:
Why there now, youſe run on at a fine rate, and Iſe does not know what youſe been jabbering about, this half hour. The Devil take all your country, ſay I: Youſe come over here, poor, ſorry, lean, ſpectacles, to take the bread out of our Engliſh
mouths, and then prate to us in outlandiſh gibberiſh, of ruelly's, villy's, and Cato's. But I'll be hanged if Mrs. Cato, that lived with my lady before ſhe ever ſaw your ugly feace, were not worth a ſhip-load on ye.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: What, you filthy animal, do you ſtand making a names of me? Spectacle! me no ſpectacle; me no wear de ſpectacle on my eyes. Ver fine indeed! I vill make complain of my lady directly; I vill maka her turna you out, you miſerable ver de terre, and I vill get de French valet for her, who ſhall know how to treat mademoiſelle de Fontange vid de propre complaiſance.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Youſe turn me out, youſe be hanged firſt. Sure one Engliſhman is able to flog a dozen of your wiſhy-waſhy ſoup-meagre munſeers, let alone ſuch a flippery, flimſey doll Margery, as you.
sp.stage: [Turning her round, and making faces at her.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, de monſter, de barbicon! je dechireray ton viſage, vid my nail.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: If youſe at that work, have at you. [Spitting in his fiſt.] Noa, damn it, they ſay ſhe is a woman, and I don't care to ſtrike her, neither. But hearkee me; ſend your fine man, your varlet, that is to treat you with compliments, and Iſe treat him with as ſound a rib-roaſting, as ever our noble generals gave his countrymen at Minden; ay, that I will.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Goodlack, what is the matter, dear mademoiſelle? you ſeem to be in a moſt piteous taking. For goodneſs ſake, Nicodemus, what have you done to poor mademoiſelle?

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Why, nothing at all, Mrs. Lucy, and Iſe ſorry for it: Thoſe damned furbeloes and flounces about her heels there, have ſaved her beacon, or I'd have trimmed her jacket for her; ay, that I would.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh! he has mada de baddeſt names of me—he calla me de ſpectacle, de marjoram—oh, oh!

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Dear mademoiſelle, do not take on ſo, though it is very affecting really. Come, Mr. Nicodemus, pray aſk mademoiſelle's pardon; come, kiſs and be friends, do now.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Iſe aſk her pardon! Iſe kiſs her! not I truly—Iſc juſt as ſoon hug an hedgehog. Let her be glad ſhe was not a mon, and go off quietly with what ſhe has gotten.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Come, dear mademoiſelle, walk in with me; your nerves ſeem mightily affected, and I have got ſome excellent hartſhorn, which I hope will compoſe you.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, de béte, de monſter!

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Diſcovers Lady FRANKLAND at her toilet, reading.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.

q.l: Where thought meets thought, ere from the lips they part,
And each warm wiſh ſprings mutual from the heart,
This ſure is bliſs, if bliſs on earth there be—

sp.p: Heigh ho! why cannot I repeat the reſt? Dear unhappy Eloiſe; but oh! far more unhappy lady Frankland! She had experienced thoſe tranſports ſhe ſo feelingly deſcribes, whilſt I, unhappy I, with all the tenderneſs of fond affections glowing in my breaſt, was doomed to the embraces of a marble ſtatue! Surely my glaſs deceives me, or I might well inſpire that ardent love which lifts us to the ſkies upon its ſeraph's wings. Cruel parents, was it for you I wedded! you choſe, indeed, a man of worth and honour for me: O, the rare gift! but to become once weary of a faultleſs perſon, is to be doomed to laſſitude for life. This ſurely, is ſevere!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Upon my word, lady Frankland, you will ſpoil thoſe fine eyes of yours, with conſtant poring; and then, I fear you will become ſo very, very wiſe too, that our beaux won't be able to converſe with you, and we ſhall abſolutely be deſerted by every creature, but the grave Sir William Belville, who I believe reads a little, and the ſagacious counſellor Frankland, learned in the laws.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I aſſure you, Emilia, I almoſt wiſh I had never learned my letters; ſor the delicate and refined ſentiments, which books have inſpired me with, have only ſerved to diſguſt me with almoſt all mankind.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: And yet you would have me read and ſigh, and weep over a parcel of doleful devils, who, ten to one, never exiſted, nor is it a farthing matter whether they did or no. Not I truly; if knowledge is to make me unhappy, I am ſure 'tis wiſdom to remain in ignorance; and I heartily wiſh dame Eve had thought ſo too.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Yet you loſe vaſt pleaſure, Emilia.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Grant it; you muſt allow that I eſcape much pain: And I am perſuaded, that your ladyſhip might have been as happy with lord Frankland, as any woman in England, if your ideas had not been perverted and diſturbed by an heap of vile romantic traſh.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: No, Emilia, it was impoſſible. But let me not accuſe my lord for this; my ill ſtars only were to blame.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Bleſs me, what had ſtars to do in that caſe?—unleſs you mean ſtars and garters; and I dare ſay his lordſhip might eaſily have obtained a red ribbon, at leaſt, if that could have rendered you happy.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: My dear wild girl, you have wandered very far from my meaning. When I accuſed my fate, in order to excuſe my lord, it was for not having afforded me ſome glorious opportunity of manifeſting a paſſion for him, by ſome noble, generous deed, which muſt have extorted his admiration, his gratitude, and love. For, to deal candidly, what right had I to have expected that lord Frankland ſhould be a paſſionate lover? what ſacrifice had I made him? by what heroic devotement had I awakened the ſenſibility of his ſoul? where was the merit of having obeyed my parents, and accepted for an huſband one, to whom I could poſſibly have no exception?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Indeed, my dear lady Frankland, you talk ſtrangely, and put me in mind of a young lady of my acquaintance, deeply verſed in romance, who, with a
large fortune, ran away with an enſign; but when they had got clear off, ſhe would not be content unleſs he returned and ſuffered her to leap out of a window to him: The experiment was made, and the poor lady diſcovered, and confined, till a more ſuitable match could be found out for her.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: With which, I ſuppoſe, ſhe was miſerable for life. Why ſhould love meddle in matches of convenience? Oh, ye delights of ſenſible ſouls! charms of impaſſioned hearts! where are ye? alas! in free and independent love alone, in the mutual yielding of two fond hearts, which have beſtowed themſelves!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Oh, for Heaven's ſake, dear lady Frankland, don't run on at this rate! I vow I am frightened leſt you ſhould tempt me to throw away myſelf and fortune, upon ſome beggar in purſuit of theſe ſame tranſports, which, after all, I do not believe are to be found any where but in the heated imagination of ſome poet or romance-monger.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I hope that my dear Emilia will experience every happineſs which ſhe can wiſh. I own your reproof is juſt, and I ſhall henceforth avoid any diſcourſe that may elevate your notions to ſuch an height, as may perhaps make you feel thoſe bitter pangs of diſappointment, which have been my lot.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: My dear lady Frankland, I had not the leaſt idea of your growing ſerious on the ſubject: But luckily here comes company to divert it. I have ſome letters to write, and ſhall return the moment they are finiſhed.
sp.stage: Enter Lady FANSHAW, CLARINDA, and Sir HARRY WILMOT.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Joy to my dear lady Frankland, joy to the world of love and gaity.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Joy to the lovers of liberty, that you have recovered yours.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I thank ye, ladies, for your congratulations; but as yet I confeſs I do not ſee of what great advantage this ſame boaſted liberty will be of to me. I have really no purſuits to follow, no inclinations to indulge, that need reſtraint; and to become one's own miſtreſs, at my age, is, I think, a thing rather to be feared than wiſhed.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why truly, madam, yours is a critical ſituation. But what is female liberty, after all, but a name? for a fine woman can never enjoy it, but in the moment ſhe renounces it; and it is only worth preſerving, in order to part with it to good purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed, Sir Harry, to hear you preach ſuch abſurd doctrine: Lady Frankland is very young; her ignorance is therefore pardonable; but give me leave, who have been my own miſtreſs theſe ten years, to inſtruct her ladyſhip in the charms and uſe of liberty, and I fancy ſhe will find there is ſomething in them more than a name.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Madam, I bow to your ſuperior judgment, and muſt confeſs I do not know a more experienced guide, to all the paths of pleaſure. You and the gay Clarinda here, would have made notable prieſteſſes,
were the myſteries of the Bona Dea now in vogue. But, madam, [to lady Frankland] I would not have your ladyſhip diſcouraged by what I have ſaid with regard to liberty, for 'tis, doubtleſs, a moſt delightful thing to be free.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: True, Sir Harry, provided one knows how to uſe that freedom; but to run gadding about the world, without meaning or deſign, is certainly a groſs abuſe of it.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Abſolute proſtitution of our greateſt bleſſing—But, in my opinion, there is but one meaſure for your ladyſhip to purſue; to chuſe a proper conductor, and leave the reſt to him. A perſon, endowed with your ladyſhip's beauty, and delicacy of ſentiment, muſt ſurely have the choice of many.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: There lies the difficulty, Sir Harry. When they who wiſhed my happineſs, as ardently as I can do, whoſe judgment and experience were far ſuperior to mine, have erred, what have I not to fear, even in the choice of a mere ſentimental friendſhip, which is all my ſituation can admit of?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip means, I ſuppoſe, in chuſing lord Frankland for your huſband.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I ſwear, for my part, I ever thought it an illſuited match.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Why, he is really a good ſort of man, and ſenſible enough too, but unhappily wants taſte; not at all cut out for diſcovering the elegant and refined charms of your ladyſhip's mind. Beſides,
really the deſire of pleaſing an huſband, is in general ſo very languid, that a fine woman ſeldom exerts her moſt amiable qualities, toward him. To charm, to conquer, ſhe reſerves for other eyes, and other hearts than his.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir Harry, I ſhould look upon myſelf as highly culpable, if that had been my caſe. My utmoſt wiſh was to inſpire lord Frankland with the moſt delicate paſſion: How I have failed, I know not!

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Oh, the ſweet plaintive turtle! Come, come, my dear, lord Frankland is a reaſonable creature; he leaves you at liberty.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: And you would be unworthy of ſuch rational treatment, ſhould you ſquander ſo great a treaſure, in idleneſs or diſſipation.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am not much afraid of falling into either of theſe extremes, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Was there ever ſo rude a monſter, as that Charles Frankland! I met him in the ante-chamber, and made him as civil a curteſy, as any third couſin could poſſibly do, and the bear came up to me, whipt me about the neck, and kiſſed me with the ſame ruſtic freedom he uſed to do at my father's in Wales, when he came circuit with the judges, and dined at our houſe.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Oh, poor Emilia! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Do ſettle my tucker, Clarinda.
So, Sir, you have followed me, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: He muſt be a dull hound, indeed, who could be found at a fault, in ſo ſhort a courſe. I am glad to ſee your ladyſhip,

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I find your ladyſhip ſo much engaged with the croud which ſurrounds you, that I ſhall, for the preſent, take my leave; but as I have ſomething of importance to communicate to you, I intreat you will allow me the honour of waiting on you this evening, when the company may be ſeated at cards, and I may have the felicity of entertaining your ladyſhip apart.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I ſhall be glad to ſee you, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I doubt it not

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Well now, my dear giddy Emilia, what is this terrible diſaſter, which you complain of?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Why, madam, all I know of the matter, is, that my couſin ſeems offended at my being glad to ſee her.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Not ſo neither, Mr. Charles; but you need not drag one's cloaths off, as you uſed to do. Beſides, I am not ſo great a romp as I was, and had not my hair dreſſed then. I am ſure he has diſconcerted it mightily; has not he, lady Fanſhaw?

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Not much, my dear.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: This fracas will ſoon be made up, I imagine. Mr. Frankland, you'll do me the pleaſure of your company to dinner. Come, ladies.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I ſhall attend your ladyſhip. [Exeunt all but Mr. Frankland.] An aſſignation ſo publicly made, I think I never ſaw: it almoſt wears the face of innocence, from indiſcretion. This is a rare place to ſeek a wife in! I think I had better play Sir Harry's game, and look out for an intrigue. Ay, ſurely, were it the woman only that I ſought: but, in that caſe, the fortune is as transferable as the laſs, and I would not give ſix-pence for the latter, without the former▪

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Lady Frankland's houſe. Mr. FRANKLAND and EMILIA.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: WELL, Mr. Frankland, now that you have drawn me from the company, prithee what is this mighty important buſineſs, you ſaid you had to communicate to me?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: How can my dear Emilia be ſo cold—aſk ſuch a cruel queſtion!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I declare I am not in the leaſt cold; I think the weather rather warm for the ſeaſon: and as to cruelty, 'tis a moſt unjuſt charge, for I vow I never hurt any thing in my life, no not a fly.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: How can you trifle thus?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Nay, but it is you that trifle, and I beg you will not detain me, for I am ſure the company within will ſit down to loo in five minutes, and I would not loſe my place at the table, for any conſideration; therefore, if you have any thing to ſay, ſpeak, vite, vite, as Fontange ſays.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Since I find, madam, that you cannot with patience ſpare a few minutes to one, whoſe every hour of life is devoted to you, I ſhall not treſpaſs on you longer, but leave you, madam, to more agreeable avocations.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: No, I ſwear you ſhall not make a fool of me, neither; I am ſure lady Frankland will aſk what buſineſs you had with me, therefore do, pray do, tell it me, directly.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: If my eyes have not already made the too preſumptuous declaration, then let my tongue avow it—Emilia, I adore you.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! and is that the mighty ſecret, labouring in your breaſt?—Why, my good couſin Charles, you ought certainly to be a great wit, for you really have a very bad memory, and ſeem utterly to forget that you have told me the ſame ſtory, by night and by day, an hundred times at leaſt, within theſe three years, and that I have always received this pompous declaration, juſt as I do at preſent—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am extremely unhappy, madam, to find that the moſt important concern of my life ſhould become a matter of ridicule and mirth to you. But though you cannot feel for others, let your own danger awaken your ſenſibility: You ſtand at preſent on the brink of ruin, and have no other place of ſafety, that I can ſee, but theſe arms, to take refuge in.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Then ſure my caſe is deſperate, indeed! But what danger, Sir, what ruin, am I threatened with?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: With one of the greateſt misfortunes that can poſſibly befal an innocent young woman—the loſs of reputation, madam.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: My character, Sir, is far above the reach of malice, nor has the tongue of ſlander ever yet pronounced my name.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: It will not long be ſilent then, be aſſured of it, aſſociated as you now are with perſons, whoſe characters have been ſo long infamous, that ſcandal has forgot their names.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I neither know, nor own ſuch vile acquaintance; but if you would not have me think you worſe, far worſe, than thoſe you have deſcribed, ſpeak out directly; name them to me, Sir, nor like a baſe aſſaſſin, attempt to wound thoſe by night, you dare not look upon by day.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: My dear Emilia, you are young, and do not ſee through the artifices of that vile woman.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: What woman? Sure you dare not hint it!

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Lady Frankland is—

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: An angel.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I ſay, a fallen one.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Oh, thou art one, and of the blackeſt dye!—She vile, ſhe artful! thou art a monſter but to think it. Her mind and perſon are as pure as mountain-ſnow, which the ſun's beams have never glanced upon.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: This is prodigious fine, very poetical truly. But now, my dear Emilia— [taking her hand].

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Stand off; there's poiſon in your touch, as in your ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Are you then deaf, as well as blind? Were you not preſent this morning, when ſhe publicly gave an aſſignation to Sir Harry Wilmot? her bed-chamber, I ſuppoſe, will be the ſcene.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Sir, I command you ſilence; let not your venomed tongue offend my ears, with ſuch baſe, ſuch vile ſuggeſtions.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You bid me ſpeak, and you ſhall hear me out. Is not the grave Sir William Belville ever ſighing at her feet, with twenty coxcombs more, who in their turns ſhall hope, nor hope in vain.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Leave me, Sir; I deſire you'll leave me.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: No, my lovely Emilia, I cannot, will not leave you: I will defend you, even againſt yourſelf. I have ſhewn you the precipice, on which you ſtand; let me now point out the path to happineſs and ſafety. This vile lady Frankland—

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Again, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Can never think of returning back to her huſband again; and, in failure of lawful iſſue, you know I am his heir; therefore no deſpicable match for my Emilia.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Thou art indeed, the moſt deſpicable, meaneſt wretch that lives. So, ſir, the ſource of this polluted ſtream, at length appears: You have traduced
one innocent woman, to entrap another. But know, that were you this moment, what I hope you never will be, in poſſeſſion of lord Frankland's wealth and honours, and that Emilia had not a ſhilling in the world, ſhe would fly you with the ſame deteſtation and contempt, ſhe does at preſent. And ſo, my lord Would-be, adieu.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I fear I have over-ſhot the mark. I thought to have frightened the little Welch puſs, with the cry of ſcandal opening againſt her, and that ſhe would have taken cover in my arms. But faith ſhe is a ſtout one, and worth ſcampering after, the whole circumference of her eſtate; and, by fair or foul means, I will yet hunt her down.
Serviteur, mademoiſelle.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, your honour's tres humble ſervante; comment ſe porte Mr. Padrick, your honour's Iris ſerviteur? he never a come to ſee us ſince a we leave Parliamentary-ſtreet. Oh, he be de inconſtant varlet!

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I ſhall take care to chide him for it, mademoiſelle, and ſend him to wait upon you directly.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, your honour maka me very, very glad. I do like Mr. Padrick dearly, he be ſo very coxcomical he maka me laugh; and then he maka de plays vid de kiſſes in it. Oh, it was very, very ſweet.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Well, mademoiſelle, Patrick ſhall certainly refreſh your lips, with ſome of thoſe ſweet kiſſes
again. But tell me, how do you like your manner of living, ſince your removal to Pall-Mall? I ſuppoſe you are quite happy here without a maſter.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, point de tout, not at all. My lady ſhe keep a de very bad hour; pauvre Fontange ſhe muſt ſit up for her lady. I am ſure me look a de vizard, for want of de ſleep.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: How happens that, mademoiſelle? what can ſhe find to do alone?

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Why ſhe have a de companie dat ſtay with her ſometime till one or two o'clok; den ſhe go up to her chambre; dere ſhe ſit down to ſigh, or to read a de great big boke; den may be, that laughing miſs Emilie ſhe come in, whip away de boke, and ſit prate-a-prate to her till we no want candle to go to bed. But I beg a your honour's pardon: I have a de lettre to my lady, from Sir Harry Wilmot.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Serviteur, mademoiſelle. Proceed in your vocation.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Your tres humble.—Pray ſouvenez monſieur Padrick.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
A letter from Sir Harry! What then, his ſtomach does not ſerve, or perhaps he thinks the treat will keep cold. I am ſorry for it. I wiſh he, or the Devil had her. I know not what to think of her. I greatly fear ſhe may be honeſt. But if I can contrive any method to ruin her in lord Frankland's opinion, 'tis quite equal, and ſhe may then remain as chaſte as ſhe pleaſes, for me. This French
woman may be of uſe: She certainly knows her lady's ſecrets; and it will be very extraordinary, if an Engliſhman's gold, and an Iriſhman's kiſſes, may not be able to open the lock of that curious repoſitory. She may aſſiſt in my deſign on Emilia too, whom I am determined to have, were it only to gratify my pique.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A drawing-room in Lady Frankland's houſe.
Lady FRANKLAND, Lady FANSHAW, CLARINDA, and Sir WILLIAM BELVILLE, ſeated at a card-table.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: The pool is out, and my cards are really ſo diſagreeable that I am tired of playing. I wiſh Emilia would come and take them.
Will you play, Emilia?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: No, madam, I would rather be excuſed, at preſent.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Then we have done, if your ladyſhip pleaſes, and I am glad of it; for I confeſs I think that play, among friends, is a moſt ſhameful miſemployment of time, and that cards appear properly in the hands of ſharpers only, merely as implements of their trade.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: For all that, Sir William, cards are a very comfortable reſource ſometimes.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Ay, where the company is not large enough to make up a country-dance.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I am ſure half the people of faſhion in England, would paſs many a dull evening, nay, perhaps ſome of them might hang or drown themſelves, if it was not for the relief which theſe little innocent paintings afford.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am ſo far of Sir William Belville's opinion, that I think avarice is the true ſource of play; and how perſons of liberal minds, and eaſy fortunes, can reconcile ſo mean a motive to themſelves, is to me ſurprizing.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: There are few people, madam, who are truly acquainted with the ſprings of their own actions, and many who are actuated by the baſeſt, would be ſhocked if they knew them.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: This is a grave ſubject, Sir William; I think we grow rather too wiſe.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Why I really think ſo too, ſo I'll e'en go trifle. O Clarinda, ſuch a capuchin as I ſaw in the Park, yeſterday! I will have juſt ſuch another poſitively, and will inſtantly go enter into cloſe conſultation with my milliner, on this important ſubject.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I wiſh Sir Harry Wilmot was here; he would enliven us all, even without cards.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: You'll not have your wiſh to-night, lady Fanſhaw—Sir Harry is engaged.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Prithee where, Clarinda?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
At lady Subtle's: He is ſolely devoted to her, for the preſent. Her huſband is in the country,
and I dare ſay he would not ſpend this evening from her, for a nabob's fortune.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Ridiculous! how can you talk ſo? why he has been in her good graces, above this month, which is long enough, believe me, to ſurfeit him. He has had a dozen amours, at leaſt, within theſe twelve months.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: A dozen, did you ſay, lady Fanſhaw?

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I did indeed; and your ladyſhip may be aſſured I have ſpoken within bounds.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I dare ſay ſo too; and yet he has behaved with honour, to them all.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: How you amaze me! with honour ſaid you? I thought till now, that conſtancy in love had been a virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I have met with ſome ſuch muſty moral, among the metaphyſics of old romances; but the bon ton of later times, have exploded it long ſince, I aſſure your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: I humbly beg a mille pardon of your ladyſhip, and of all de ladyſhips, for me entre here; but I have a beg of Nicodumpus this half-hour, to bring a this lettre to your ladyſhip; but he pretend a he do not entendez moi, and I am forced to bring it myſelf, for which I beg a mille pardon again.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Give it to me, mademoiſelle.—I ſhall return immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Each word, each glance, diſcovers ſome new charm, And dead, not cold, is he ſhe cannot warm.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: O fye, Sir William! what a mere whining inamorato you are! why don't you ſay all theſe fine things to her face? what ſignifies your ſighing them out, after ſhe has got beyond ear-ſhot?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: The delicate and high reſpect I bear toward her ladyſhip's unhappy ſituation, muſt ſeal my lips in everlaſting ſilence; nor ſhall I ever breathe a ſigh or wiſh, that may offend her.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW and CLARINDA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: And ſo you think ſhe would be offended! Lord, Sir William, though you are very young, you need not pretend to be quite ſo innocent. Offended! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am pleaſed to hear you ſo merry, ladies. Prithee communicate the occaſion; for I ſhould be glad to try if there be ſympathy in mirth, as well as contagion in ſorrow. Do tell me what you laugh at.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Lady Fanſhaw and Clarinda, madam, were ſaying—

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: What, pray?

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Why, that of all ſimple animals, a baſhful lover was the moſt ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I believe there are few men, now-a-days, ridiculous on that account. I have, indeed, read of lovers who have ſighed whole years away, without daring to acquaint the happy object with their paſſion.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: While, perhaps, the pining fair one ſat ſighing, in her turn, to waving woods and purling ſtreams, for him again. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: That too might have happened, I believe, Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: And don't your ladyſhip think they were a couple of mighty ſilly mortals?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You know my ſentiments upon that ſubject, already, ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: For my part, I think there is happineſs ſufficient, in the bare loving of an amiable object.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: What, without any hope or deſire of a return?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: It is impoſſible to diveſt a lover of the fond hope of being pitied, at leaſt, by the object he adores; and while he confines his wiſhes within that bound, he is indeed a lover: but when he vainly thinks his ſervices ſhould merit a reward, perhaps inconſiſtent with the honour or happineſs of the beloved object, ſelf-love aſſumes the place of paſſion, and it no longer deſerves even the name.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Upon my word, Sir William, I am charmed with the elegant and juſt deſcription you have given of
love, and am rejoiced to find the dear idea ſtill exiſts in any breaſt beſides my own.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: They muſt be inſenſible, indeed, who could have had the happineſs of converſing with your ladyſhip, without being, in ſome degree, inſpired by that delicacy and refinement, which accompany all your words and actions; and if I have been able to conceive, or expreſs proper ſentiments of the nobleſt paſſion, I own myſelf indebted for them, to my knowledge of lady Frankland.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: This goes on ſwimmingly; let us leave them together; I dare ſay they wiſh us gone, Clarinda.— [To Lady Frankland.] We muſt bid your ladyſhip good evening: Clarinda and I are under an engagement to meet lady Rattle, and ſome other company at Vauxhall.
sp.stage: [Sir William bows to Lady Frankland at the ſame time, as taking leave.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: You are not coming with us, Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: No, madam, but I think it time alſo to retire. I wiſh your ladyſhip good-night.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Stupid fellow! I would not have gone away theſe two hours, if I had thought ſo.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Sir William Belville is really a very agreeable and polite man. Oh, if lord Frankland had been capable of his refined, his delicate ſentiments of love, how happy had I been! this were indeed the golden age again reſtored to me!—But let me ſee once more, what ſays the gay Sir Harry?
"Madam,

"I am totally in deſpair at loſing the moſt precious moments of my life; but company have broke in upon me, and prevented my laying my devoirs at your feet. What would I not give to eſcape from them! but, unluckily, they are perſons of the firſt condition:—I cannot therefore taſte of happineſs, till to-morrow. I moſt earneſtly conjure dear lady Frankland, to abridge ſome hours of cruel and diſtracting abſence, by permitting me to attend her levee at the toilet: 'Till then I have the honour to be
Her ladyſhip's moſt paſſionate adorer,
H. WILMOT."
Vain coxcomb! is this then the important buſineſs he had to communicate to me? But I will ſee him, to mortify the inſolence of his preſumption.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Pray, what is your ladyſhip ruminating ſo very ſeriouſly upon?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I have much to think of, Emilia; but I promiſed you this morning, you may remember, to confine my ideas to my own breaſt. I fancy you look grave too: what, has Mr. Frankland boiſterouſly preſumed to kiſs your hand, or neglected to take up your fan, when you dropt it on purpoſe for him? or—

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: No ſuch matters, I aſſure your ladyſhip. Yet he has indeed furniſhed me with a very copious ſubject for contemplation. But—

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I claim no right over your ſecrets, my dear; and from the good opinion I have formed of your character,
I dare ſay you may be ſafely truſted with the keeping of them yourſelf. But, as I moſt ſincerely wiſh your happineſs, I muſt ſay, that I think you would have a better chance for it with any other man, than Mr. Frankland: There is a reſerve, even in his gayeſt manners, that ſeems to ſquint ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I am ſo far of your ladyſhip's opinion, that I promiſe you Mr. Frankland ſhall never have it in his power to render me unhappy. But let us talk no more upon ſo diſagreeable a ſubject. I have juſt got the laſt new ſong, that your ladyſhip ſeemed fond of: will you ſtep into the next room, and hear it with the harpſichord?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: With all my heart.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Mr. Frankland's chambers in the Temple.
Mr. FRANKLAND muſing. Enter PATRICK with a letter.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You have ſtaid a confounded while; but I ſuppoſe you waited for an anſwer—Give it to me.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Fait, and if I had done that, myſelf would not have been here ſo ſoon itſelf; for how could miſs Emilia give an anſwer to a letter ſhe would not read, unleſs ſhe was a conjuror, or a witch?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Not read my letter!

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p:
Not ſhe indeed; ſhe ſcorned the motion, though mademoiſelle palavered her at the greateſt rate, and ſaid ſhe was ſure it muſt be very pretty, when it
would come from the young concealor; but madam Emilia ſhe ſaid ſhe would not pry into the concealment; that is, ſhe would not break the ſeal, I ſuppoſe. Augh, ſhe is very witty.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Leave your nonſenſical prate, and be gone.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Well, there is your letter for you again, ſafe and ſound; not a bit worſe than when you gave it me—O yes, fait, it has got a little clean dirt in my pocket, but that's no great ſignify, it will ſerve a poor body well enough ſtill. Shall I carry it to Mrs. Suſan Taper in Threadneedle-ſtreet? may be it would bid her bring home the ſhirts, if ſhe is able to carry them, with the load your honour has given her already.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Blockhead, give me the letter.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Fait, that's very fooliſh now. I am ſure your honour was a full hour a writing it; and what do you throw it away for?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Leave the room. [Exit Patrick.] The inſolence of this proud girl, diſtracts me. I fear I am on the brink of ruin: my fortune mortgaged for more than it is worth; my honour pawned at play; and, what is worſe, my credit ſunk with her, who was to have redeemed them all! ſhould ſhe acquaint lord Frankland with what I have ſaid of his wife, his fooliſh fondneſs for her honour may make him caſt me off, both from his heart and fortune. Beggary, contempt, and infamy, ſtare in my face. I muſt find out ſome means to avoid their frowns, or elſe eſcape from them by the help of a piſtol: but as that is at any time in my power, I'll make one effort more, before I draw the trigger, and deſerve death, at leaſt, before I fly to it.

div.head: SCENE I.

q.l: TO climates chear'd by other ſuns,
In vain the wretched exile runs;
Or tho' he mount the rapid ſteed,

div.p: How ſtrongly do I feel the force of this ſentiment in my own breaſt! I hoped the opening charms of the ſoft breathing ſpring, would have removed my languor; I grew ſick of the country in a few hours, and I ſhall probably be tired of London, in as ſhort a ſpace.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: I hope I ſee your lordſhip in good health; your ſudden return has alarmed me.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I thank you, Ambroſe; but I am as well as ever I expect to be!

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: My deareſt lord, you break my heart to hear you talk ſo ſadly. If your old ſervant gueſſes right, your malady is love—Love for the ſweeteſt, beſt of women, your lordſhip's wife. Oh! ſhe is all made up of gentleneſs and generoſity! I wonder, indeed I do, how you could have the heart to part with her, indeed I do, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Full well I know her exquiſite perfections, Ambroſe, and admire them all. But with a heart that lov'd as mine did, how could I bear daily to be reproached with want of tenderneſs and paſſion for her! I found it impoſſible to act up to her romantic notions; and as I could not make her happy, I determined not to make her wretched, tho' 'tis too ſure that ſhe has rendered me ſo.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: I am certain, my lord, her gentle heart would break, if ſhe ſuſpected that you grieved for her. She ever has received your poor old ſervant with the greateſt kindneſs, and made me even ſit down before her, when ſhe thought that I looked feeble or fatigued, while ſhe inquired minutely of your lordſhip's health. Then let me go to her, and tell her what I am ſure your lordſhip thinks, I know ſhe will hear me, indeed ſhe will—Oh! on my knees I beg that I may be the bleſſed meſſenger of peace, the happy cauſe of your re-union!

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I command you not to attempt it. [The pride of manhood and of love forbid it: could I have condeſcended to have whined and ſighed before her, we never ſhould have parted; but ſince that has happened, nothing but a full conviction of the injury ſhe has done my love, ſhall ever make us meet again. Mean time, I will watch over her, like her guardian angel, and ſhield her from each wrong, or violence, ſhe brings not on herſelf. Should that e'er happen, my care is at an end.] [Aſide.] Go, Ambroſe, and inquire her health, and let Emilia know I ſhould be glad to ſee her. But for your life, breathe not a ſyllable of what has paſt.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: I will obey your lordſhip, tho' 'tis the firſt ſevere command you ever laid upon me.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You will find me in the library.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Lady Frankland juſt riſen from dreſſing. Fontange ſettling the toilet.
Enter Sir HARRY, and exit FONTANGE.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Bright as the ſun, and as the morning fair! Eh, ma charmante! what an amazing freſhneſs of complexion! what a profuſion of lovely hair! upon my ſoul, lady Frankland, you are vaſtly handſome.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am glad to ſee you in ſuch top ſpirits, Sir Harry. I ſuppoſe them the effect of your laſt night's party.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Laſt night—Let me conſider, where was I laſt night? Oh the curſed embarras du monde! which prevented my waiting on your ladyſhip. I have a vaſt mind to turn ſhepherd, and renounce the world at once. Should not you like to be a ſhepherdeſs now?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: O vaſtly! with ſuch a faithful ſwain.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Egad, and ſo I am. Conſtancy is, I think, my greateſt foible, at preſent.—'Tis apt to wear out a miſtreſs's patience.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Then lady Subtle may boaſt of her charms, if they have been powerful enough to ſix the lively, roving, Sir Harry Wilmot.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Lady Subtle! why you know, ma chere, her charms are in the wane, abſolutely expiring—We have been old acquaintance, and it would have been cruel in me to have refuſed her the ſhadow of an amour, when ſhe is ſo very near becoming a ghoſt. I am glad to find ſhe is jealous.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Is ſhe in a bad ſtate of health, Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: O, by no means, ſhe is as fat and florid as any woman in England of her age, which I believe is near forty.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Pray where is the danger then, of her becoming a ghoſt?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Helas, ma chere innocente! don't you meet a thouſand ghoſts in every public place? Bodies without ſouls, who have haunted the world ſo long, that they are worn out of every one's remembrance, and might glide in and out, without ever being taken notice of, if it were not for the ſpace they occupy. Have you never been joſtled by a fat red ghoſt, in the box lobby of the playhouſe,
or at the puppet-ſhow caſcade at Vauxhall? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: As they differ in every reſpect from ſpirits, I ſhould never have thought of ſtiling them ghoſts, tho', as you have explained it, I own the term is apt enough; yet I fancy that blanks would do ſtill better, as ſome authors have lately uſed them, merely to make up bulk, and ſtuff life's volume.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I vow, madam, your ladyſhip has an infinity of wit, as well as beauty. But now, prithee, dear lady Frankland, what do you ſeriouſly mean to do with them both?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I do not find myſelf overburthen'd with either of thoſe rare qualities, Sir Harry; but if I ſhould, I muſt e'en look out for ſome good-natured perſon, who will be kind enough to aſſiſt me in bearing the load.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Ay, now your ladyſhip talks reaſon. Mutual offices are the very bands of ſociety. And among the croud of adorers, who bow before your ſhrine, have you yet fixed on one whom you think equal to ſo bleſt a charge? I may be impertinent—Your ladyſhip's bluſhes ſeem to hint as much.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: No, Sir Harry, a heart like mine has nothing to diſguiſe—If I bluſhed, it was not ſhame, but pride, that glowed upon my cheek, from the ſlight notion you ſeem to have conceived of me, that among the trifling characters which frequent my drawing room, there could be found one capable of attaching my confidence, or regards.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why, that is vaſtly ſevere now, when there are ſuch a number of pretty fellows, who dedicate their ſervices to your ladyſhip. What pains ſhe takes to ſhew me ſhe is not engaged?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: It would be the height of vanity in me, to ſet down their viſits to my own account, Sir Harry, while I am bleſt with a companion in my houſe, whoſe mind is free, and perſon diſengag'd, and where each charm that can attract in both, unite in my Emilia.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Faith I have always heard your ladyſhip reckoned a little romantic, but never believed it till now. Emilia! why we know her price is matrimony, to become a property for life, egad. And ſure no man of ſpirit would condeſcend to ſuch terms, unleſs with a view to lord Frankland's circumſtances, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Sir, you grow inſolent.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I vow I did not mean it, and aſk a thouſand pardons—but ſurely, madam, with that blaze, that glow of youth and beauty which ſurrounds you, it is impoſſible you ſhould think of living diſengag'd! Were the Heſperian fruit planted in our ſtreets, it would require ten dragons to ſecure it. Alas! you have not one.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: In this imminent danger, what think you of my appointing ſuch an excellent guardian as Sir Harry Wilmot? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: You may gibe if you pleaſe, madam, but I certainly ſhould be the very thing, if I were not ſo much engag'd. Lord, what ſhall I do for means to get free!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Pray do not give yourſelf the leaſt trouble upon that account, Sir Harry, for tho' I am, as you obſerved, a little romantic, I have not bravery ſufficient to turn knight-errant; and I muſt ſurpaſs even the renowned Don Quixote, ſhould I think of encountering the numerous hoſt of rivals which your attachment might enrage.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: No, madam, your ladyſhip is miſtaken, there are not a vaſt number, who at this time lay claim to my devoirs.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: O but, Sir Harry, my heart is ſo very tender, that I ſhould be moved to reſtore you back to the groans of lady Subtle, or the firſt ſtalking ſhade of thoſe numberleſs ghoſts your cruelty has made, that might come to haunt me for you.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I aſſure your ladyſhip you are wrong to make a jeſt of my behaviour to lady Subtle; there are few men of my rank in life, who have either morals, or politeneſs, ſufficient to pay the leaſt regard to a dying reputation.—Now, madam, it has ever been my principle and practice both, never publickly to abandon a miſtreſs; and when I have been inſufferably tired of a lady, I have kept my chamber, and ſeen no company for three days together, in order to give her the credit of the rupture. But you are not to expect ſuch nice morals from the generality of men, I'll aſſure you, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: How you amaze me! is this, Sir Harry, what you ſtile morals, principles, politeneſs! to betray, to expoſe a wretched woman! ſurely I am in a dream, I cannot think myſelf awake.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why truly, madam, I think we are both very near taking a nap; we have wandered from the point ſtrangely; and I ought to beg your ladyſhip's pardon, for having made ſo improper an uſe of the favour you have indulged me in. Eh donc, ma belle, will you now ſeriouſly fix upon the happy man, who is to love and be beloved by you?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You increaſe my aſtoniſhment every ſyllable you utter.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: She muſt be very ignorant, to be ſo ſubject to wonder.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am young, perhaps not inſenſible; but neither my youth nor ſenſibility ſhall ever betray me into imprudence. If my affections are to be gained, it muſt be time, aſſiduity, reflection, the ſoft habitudes of friendſhip and eſteem, that muſt obtain them, even without my choice.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I admire you vaſtly, madam, upon my ſoul I do—but I have not the honour to be of the antient chivalry; nor had I the leaſt notion of your ladyſhip's allowing me the happineſs of a tête à tête, merely to aſſiſt you in compoſing a romance. Adieu, donc, ma chere princeſſe, belle heroine, adieu.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Where will my wonder end! Is this the man of gallantry, the irreſiſtable Sir Harry Wilmot! Surely that woman muſt firſt be a dupe to her own paſſions, who could comply with his. Not ſuch the lovers I have read of, who ſighed whole years in ſilence, nor to the world revealed their bitter anguiſh, their conſuming pain; the whiſpering woods alone were conſcious of their woe, till echo caught the ſound, and bore it on her dying voice to the beloved fair.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM BELVILLE.
sp.p: This charming woman fills up all my thoughts, my every wiſh is her's, nay my whole ſoul! What delicacy of ſentiment, what elegance of form and manners! Happy—rather ſay unhappy lord Frankland, whoſe ſure poſſeſſion made him contemn a prize, that kings might become rivals for.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why ſo grave, Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: You miſtake, Sir Harry, I was only thoughtful.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why curſe me if ever I could diſtinguiſh between thought and gravity, in all my life; and as I look upon reflexion to be a mere dull mechanic ſort of buſineſs, I have reſolved never to think, while I live.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: A moſt rational reſolution, truly!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: But, my dear Sir William, egad I had like to have forgot—you are under the higheſt obligation to me, this very moment; and I will be thanked, poſitively I will.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: You need but name it, Sir Harry, and reſt aſſured of my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why then, Sir Knight, I have atchieved ſuch a feat in your favour, as you will be tranſported at—cleared the cover'd way, my boy, and left the defile open to you, and you alone. But not to arrogate too much, I muſt confeſs that it was pure want of that noble ſpirit of perſeverance, which you are ſo amply poſſeſſed of, that made me quit the aſſault; for to ſay the truth, I am tolerable enough at a ſkirmiſh, but deviliſh bad at a ſiege.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: You ſpeak in riddle, Sir Harry, pray explain yourſelf, that I may thank you as I ought.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Well then, my dear Belville, thus the matter ſtands—We have both of us, you know, ſighed for that Delia, that Caſſandra, that queen of all romance, lady Frankland.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Sir Harry, lady Frankland has a huſband, and—

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Sir William, I know ſhe has, and—they are parted; but ſuppoſe they lived together; is it not poſſible to fall in love with another man's wife?
anſwer me that, and from your heart, my grave Sir William Belville.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: A paſſion in that place, muſt be an hopeleſs one.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Not at all, I aſſure you; for if I would but have ſtarved on hope, for a few days, I might have lived on certainty, as long as I lik'd it after. But egad, my conſtitution is not ſtrong enough to faſt through a lent, though I were ſure to feaſt at the carnival.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Sir Harry, I hope ſtill I do not underſtand you; lady Frankland's character is free from blame.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: And always ſhall be ſo, for me, I aſſure you; but to be plain, Sir William, her ladyſhip did me the honour of an aſſignation, this morning, for all that.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: An aſſignation, Sir Harry!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Ay, poſitively, a tête à tête.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Go on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Go on, Sir! egad I don't know whether I ſhall or no. I fancy I have miſtaken my man, and inſtead of talking to my old friend, Will. Belville, have ſtumbled on ſome country couſin, who, becauſe he is related to her ladyſhip, thinks it incumbent on his honour, to vindicate her's. Go on, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Diſtraction! torture! [Aſide.] Sir Harry, I was only impatient to know the reſult of this aſſignation.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: To be ſhort then, her ladyſhip aſſumed all the airs of an heroine in romance, talked of conſtancy, aſſiduity, friendſhip, eſteem—and modeſtly gave me to underſtand, that I muſt dangle ſome months, at leaſt, after her, before ſhe could think of rewarding my labour. Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: But did ſhe promiſe to be kind upon theſe terms, Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why, not expreſly indeed; but ſure, Belville, you and I are too well acquainted with the ſex, not to know that a conſtant attendance for a fortnight, a few warm ſighs, ſome drops of heat diſtilling from the eyes, with a volley of flattery planted againſt her ears, would have carried this proud princeſs captive, and made her fink into my arms.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Sir Harry, notwithſtanding the lightneſs of your manners, I have ever believed you to be a man of honour; I muſt therefore ſuppoſe, that you have framed this ſtory, purely to try my opinion and regards for lady Frankland; and that on that diſcovery, you will freely own the falſehood.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: The falſehood, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Yes Sir—to traduce that lady's honour, is the baſeſt, meaneſt falſehood. She grant you an aſſignation!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: By heaven, ſhe did.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: By heaven, 'tis falſe, and thus I will aſſert it.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Nay then, have at you, in defence of truth.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: In defence of honour.
sp.stage: Enter CLARINDA at the ſide of the ſtage.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what's the matter!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Sir William, my life is in your hands.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Then take it freely. I hope you are not hurt.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Not much. If you know how to uſe it, this adventure will be a vaſt advantage to you. A conquering lover is a treaſure in romance, virtue is her fort, but ſentiment her foible. Help me to my chair, 'tis at the park gate, my wound grows painful, and the walks begin to fill. Do not boaſt of this affair to any one but lady Frankland.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Upon my honour, I ſhall not, even to her, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Succeſs attend you, you deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
To deſerve is to obtain, Sir Harry; for he who founds his ſchemes in honour, has already ſecured
to himſelf that ſelf-applauſe which is more precious than any other gratification can poſſibly be.
sp.stage: [Exeunt. Sir Harry leaning on Sir William.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: "Virtue is her fort, but ſentiment her foible." That muſt be lady Frankland. 'Tis very odd, now, I have coquetted with half a dozen at once, and have been kind to two or three, and yet never had the honour of a duel being ſought for me, tho' I have endeavoured to ſet the men together by the ears, with all my might. But theſe ſly, ſlow things, that have either the reality, or appearance of virtue, do fifty times more miſchief, than we good natur'd, generous hearted girls are capable of doing. Or perhaps our gallants, like our nation, love fighting for fighting ſake, without any hopes of being paid for it.
Oh Emilia! ſuch a dreadful accident!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what has happened?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: A duel between Sir William Belville, and Sir Harry Wilmot.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: How did it end?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I fear 'tis all over, with poor Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: But Sir William, dear Clarinda, what of him!

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: So, my little ſly one, you are caught, I ſind—

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Can one hear of bloodſhed, without concern?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: But why diſtinguiſh between the combatants?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Pſhaw, prithee tell me the whole of this ſtory?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Prithee firſt tell me, whether your emotion ariſes from ſentiment, or paſſion?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Neither, neither; compaſſion all.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Well then, all I know of the matter is, that juſt now as I entered the park, I ſaw theſe gentlemen both draw their ſwords, and engage; and before I could get up to the place, Sir William had become maſter of Sir Harry's ſword.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Were they both wounded?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I cannot inform you, I know Sir Harry was.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Surely the provocation muſt have been great that could tempt them to draw in the park. I thought Sir William had more temper and prudence. Do you know the ſubject of this quarrel?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I know there was a woman in the caſe, whom I dare pronounce to be lady Frankland.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Impoſſible! what right have either of them to aſperſe or vindicate her fame? She neither does, nor can belong to either of them.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: That is perhaps, the very reaſon why they fought about her. A woman in her circumſtances, is looked upon as lawful plunder, to which the longeſt ſword gives a title.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: My dear unhappy friend, I am grieved to the heart for her. I was going to viſit lord Frankland, juſt acroſs the park, but I ſhall firſt return to her for a few minutes. I intreat, Clarinda, that you will not mention this affair to any mortal.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Not I, you may depend upon it. The ſecret would burſt me. [Aſide.] But ſhall I ſend to know how Sir William does?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Pſhaw, I hope he is not hurt, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Farewell, Emilia.
sp.stage: As Emilia is going out, ſhe is met by Mr. Frankland.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am fortunate, madam, in meeting you in a place, where you cannot avoid me.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: You are much miſtaken, Sir, if you think it is not what I would wiſh to do in every place.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I have no reaſon to doubt your ſincerity, madam, but it was carrying your cruelty too far, to refuſe reading my letter—No judge condemns unheard.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I have heard you, Sir, and from your own lips condemn you, nor can any of your artful palliatives ever induce me to change my opinion. I therefore requeſt that you will ſpare yourſelf and me the fruitleſs trouble of attempting it; for be aſſured, that I will never receive letter or meſſage, nor hold converſe or commerce with you more.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake hear me one word, my Emilia!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: No, Sir. But to rid you of perhaps your greateſt uneaſineſs, I promiſe you I never ſhall repeat the vile calumny you thought proper to inſult me with; ſo that your ſecret remains ſafer, even in a woman's breaſt, than it was in your own. But for the future, I adviſe you to be more cautious.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: So then, all is ſafe with regard to lord Frankland I find.—But what an aſs am I to think myſelf ſo, while I am in the power of a woman? no, that can never be, till ſhe is in mine.
Well Patrick, have you ſeen Fontange?

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Yes, pleaſe your honour, I have ſeen her all over.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: What's all over?

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Why by my ſhoul ſhe is all over impudence, I think.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Why faith, when I enquir'd for her below, they ſaid ſhe was above; ſo up I went to the top of the houſe, to the very garret, to her chambray, as ſhe call'd it, and knocked at the door, out of pure civility, ſhe anſwer'd, enter, or entry, or ſomething like that; ſo in I went, and found her ſowing on her bodices, without ſo much as an apron or bedgown about her ſhoulders—augh, ſhe has made me ſick about the heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You are plaguy dainty, truly, to be offended at ſeeing a woman half naked.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Augh hone, my jewel, if it was one of my own country girls, with a ſkin as white as a crud, or a new potatoe, it would not have affected my ſtomach that way.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Well, hold your nonſenſe—did ſhe promiſe to come to my chambers?

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Faith, honey, it is but aſk and have with her. I'll be bound ſhe is there already.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: And you, blockhead, have got the keys, run home directly, I'll follow you as quick as poſſible, fly—

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Troth let her wait, I'll not fly a ſtep for her.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Be gone.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A drawing-room in Lady FRANKLAND's houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: YOU cannot imagine, my dear Emilia, how much I am ſhocked at what you have told me. I fear I ſhall now become a common topic of diſcourſe. What a triumph for lord Frankland! his character will riſe upon the ruin of mine.—Good heaven, what will become of me!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear lady Frankland, you firſt deceive yourſelf, and then argue right, upon wrong principles. You muſt certainly imagine lord Frankland a monſter, before you can ſuppoſe it poſſible for him to rejoice at your diſhonour. On the contrary, I am certain he would be ſenſible of the higheſt concern, were he acquainted even with your preſent diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: O! do not ſay ſo, Emilia, I can bear his reſentment better than his pity. I fear I have deſerved the one, and am certain I have no claim to the other.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
You judge too hardly of yourſelf, my dear; but I have ſtrong hopes that this unlucky affair will never reach his, or any other ears. Sir Harry has nothing to boaſt of; we may therefore depend on his ſilence; and I have too good an opinion of Sir William Belville, to ſuppoſe him capable of ever
mentioning it; and I would not have your ladyſhip ſeem to know one word of the matter.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Grant it ſhould remain a ſecret, Emilia; how painful muſt my ſituation be! conſcious of the higheſt obligation, which I muſt not acknowledge, even to the generous hand that has conferr'd it To a mind open and grateful as mine, this muſt be torture.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Have a care, lady Frankland, of over-rating the obligation. Sir William knows that your ſituation cannot admit of a return, and if I am not much deceiv'd with regard to his character, his ſentiments are too generous to expect one.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: By ſhewing my want of power to repay it, you but enhance the debt.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Sir William Belville, madam.
sp.stage: Lady Frankland looks at Emilia in ſome confuſion.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Your ſervant, ladies, I ſcarce expected the pleaſure of finding you at home this fine day, when all the world is abroad.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: That may perhaps be one reaſon for our ſtaying at home, Sir William. I hate crowds of every kind.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
If half the world could entertain themſelves or others, as either of you ladies can, there would
ſcarce be ſuch a thing as a crowd: ſelect parties and rational converſation, would then become the faſhion. But when the mind is vacant of ideas; its activity will ſeek them from outward objects, which ſtrike upon the ſenſes, yet leave no more impreſſion, than our forms do on a looking glaſs; while the charms of refined ſenſe, and elegant converſe, remain indelible upon the ſoul.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: For my part, Sir William, I relinquiſh any ſhare in that very fine compliment, for I confeſs I have great pleaſure in ſeeing a number of well dreſſed people together, looking as if they were pleaſed themſelves, and wiſhing to pleaſe others; and I ſhould certainly have been in the park an hour ago, if I had not ſtaid in compliment to her ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You render me uneaſy, Emilia, pray do not ſuffer your complaiſance for me to treſpaſs on your pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Tho' you modeſtly refuſe it, madam, you have ſtill a part in the eulogium; nor is it for want of ideas in yourſelf, but to inſpire them in others, that you need ever wiſh to appear in public; and who that ſees Emilia, muſt not be captivated with the pleaſing one of ſprightly innocence?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Ay, but then, Sir William, it leaves no more impreſſion, than our forms do on a looking glaſs, you know, ſo I'll even vaniſh away.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: All forms, however pleaſing, are tranſient, I confeſs; but when animated by a noble mind, they then become ſuch ſubſtances as ſtars are made of.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Then ſure my dear Emilia may ſhine forth the morning's harbinger, for never was there yet a nobler mind join'd to a fairer perſon.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: The compariſon had been more juſt, madam, had you alluded to our nightly planet, which borrows its reflected light from the bright ſun, as ſhe from you.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Your compliment is ſo very high, Sir William, that there is no replying to it. We ſeem to have got beyond the clouds, and had better beware the fate of Icarus.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: It were falling indeed, madam, to deſcend to any terreſtrial ſubject, while I have the happineſs of contemplating, and converſing with a ſeraph.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir William, your extravagant politeneſs diſtreſſes me; yet I confeſs my foible, if it is one, in being pleaſed at being approved and eſteemed by a perſon of your refined ſentiments. I hope too, that it is a pleaſure I may indulge with innocence.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Tranſporting ſound! my raptures are too ſtrong for expreſſion. Thus give me leave to thank you.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Oh! Sir William! beware of ecſtaſies! they are, alas, inconſiſtent with my hapleſs lot!

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Never, madam, ſhall I aſpire to higher bliſs, than what I now enjoy.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir William, I have been led too far▪—But ſtill remember, Sir, that I am bound by the ſtrongeſt ties. They muſt be preſerved inviolate; and if I am really dear to you, you will ever hold them ſacred.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Far, far from Belville's heart, be every wiſh for tranſient joys, attended by remorſe; much ſooner would he die, than e'er create a pang in the ſoft boſom of ſair innocence.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Lady Fanſhaw, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I vow you are a moſt unaccountable creature, lady Frankland, I have waited for you this full hour; and what is worſe, I am afraid the auction is begun, and the room ſo ſtuff'd, that we ſhall not be able to ſee the beautiful pagoda, nor get into the circle among the men; but be jamm'd up in ſome obſcure nook among the canaille, who frequent ſuch places, merely to ſtare at their betters, and poiſon the air with the fumes of tobacco.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I aſk your ladyſhip many pardons—I utterly forgot to order a card to be ſent, to let you know I could not attend you this morning.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Vaſtly polite, truly—not go with me! after preventing my being there two hours ago, and getting a ſeat cloſe to the auctioneer! I ſhould have had the very beſt place, ma'am, Mr. Langford and I are very well acquainted.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: By your own account, madam, her ladyſhip has done you a favour, by preventing you from being ſqueez'd up in a crowd.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: You are vaſtly miſtaken, Sir, there is nothing more pleaſant, and healthful too; and I am certain half the people of faſhion in London would die of fevers, if it were not for the benefit of perſpiration, which they can only receive in ſuch places, as they are too delicate to uſe exerciſe ſufficient to procure it any other way.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: This is really, madam, the only rational argument I ever heard urged in favour of a crowd; and I ſhall henceforth conſider myſelf, or any of my friends in ſuch a ſituation, as only ſuffering a painful operation for the benefit of health.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: But now, dear lady Frankland, you have not an idea of what you will loſe, if you don't come with me directly; there's my lord Mount Faſhion, who has travelled thro' Perſia, and the Mogul's country, purely to acquire a knowledge in painting and architecture, makes his firſt public appearance there this morning; and will decide exactly, with regard to the value of the bronzes, and the antiquity of the china.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Such a virtuoſo muſt be equally an honour and advantage to his country, ſurely!

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
O but, Sir William, they ſay he is a mighty pretty fellow too; in ſhort, all the pretty fellows in Town will be there.—Do come, for heaven's ſake, lady Frankland! I ſhall break my heart if I don't
go, and I can't decently ſtalk in alone, like one that nobody knows.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Rather than your ladyſhip ſhould ſuffer ſo extreme a diſappointment, come then, I will accompany you.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
