sp.p: Away, away then, quickly my dear, my chariot is at the door. Your's Sir William.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Sir William, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Lord Mount Faſhion, and all the pretty fellows in town there! ſure that could not be the motive for her going.—Yet ſhe abſolutely refuſed, till they were mentioned; nor once deſired me to accompany her. This is ſtrange! Oh! ſhe is too dear to my fond heart! I cannot bear that other men ſhould gaze upon her charms; for if they do, they'll love. I'll follow at a diſtance and obſerve her, ſhe will attract all eyes, and I may paſs unnotic'd.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: So you think, Emilia, that lady Frankland reads too much!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I do indeed, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Were her books well choſen, that could hardly be; but I fear her ſtudies ſerve rather to augment,
than amend her only foible. But pray, Emilia, who are lady Franlkand's chief intimates? I do not mean the crowds that fill her drawing room, but thoſe who are admitted en famille.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Does your lordſhip mean men or women?

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Both, Emilia; but more particularly the latter; for I would have you and every woman I regard, more nice in the choice of their female, even than their male acquaintance. Believe me much depends upon it.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Lady Fanſhaw and Clarinda are, I think, the moſt intimate of our female friends; Sir Harry Wilmot and Sir William Belville are more frequently with us, than any other men.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You ſurprize me, Emilia! Clarinda intimate with lady Frankland! I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: And why, my lord? Clarinda is ſprightly, ſenſible, and chearful.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Beware of that ſpirit, ſenſe, and gaiety, Emilia, which have not virtue for their baſe! they are dangerous inſtruments in dangerous hands! I am ſhock'd at her intimacy with my wife, which ſhe has compaſſed ſince our ſeparation; and if I have yet any influence with lady Frankland, or with you, you will both immediately quit all connection there. The reſt of the perſons you have named, I am unacquainted with, except Sir William Belville, who bears the character of a man of honour. Clarinda! lady Frankland! thoſe names ought never to be joined.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I am very certain, my lord, that lady Frankland would ſacrifice any thing on earth to your deſire. I will anſwer for it that ſhe gives up Clarinda directly. I promiſe your lordſhip that I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Do not flatter me, Emilia; could ſhe have ſacrific'd her only foible to my fond love, we had been bleſt indeed!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Pardon me, my lord, if I ſuſpect that foible might have been cured, if proper means had been applied.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Do not ſpeak of it, Emilia; my wounds all bleed afreſh. There was no way to cure it, nor could we have lived on any terms, but by indulging it to an exceſs, which muſt have rendered us both contemptible. I am impatient till you ſee my wife; alas! all that remains to me of that endearing name, is that fair ſhadow [pointing to the picture.] Let her break off all further commerce with Clarinda, if ſhe regards her own honour, or my peace.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Your lordſhip need not doubt your being obey'd.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I am grieved at thinking what may be the event of this connection. All women who have forfeited their own title to virtue, envy thoſe who poſſeſs it; and would wiſh to ſink them to their own baſe level. I am certain lady Frankland is virtuous, open, and ſincere. But alas! what arms are theſe, to combat the charms of flattery, the attractions of
pleaſure, and the ſnares of ſeduction! ſhould ſhe ſink under them. I ſurely am to blame, who have expoſed her youth and inexperience to a trial, perhaps too hard. But ſhould ſhe paſs this more than ordeal fire, unſullied and unhurt, ſhe will be ſomething more than woman; and adoration, late her claim, will then become her due. I'll hope the beſt.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: What can my maſter, and that ugly mademoiſelle there, be doing in the bed-chamber within, this full half hour together? Sure the devil would not put an ill thing in his head. Faith myſelf will peep through the key-hole, and try. [Looks in.] No ſuch thing, at all; they are talking very faſt tho', and there can't be no great harm ſure, in liſt'ning to their diſcourſe, ſince it would not be about love. [Claps his ear to the key-hole.] O faith, here they come, and a body may hear ſomething now.
sp.stage: [Retires to the ſide of the ſcene.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Upon a my • ord, conceleur, I do run a de very great dangere for your ſervice. Madame Emilic ſhe be de heireſs you know, and that do make a it de hanging matter for pauvre Fontange. Ah! Morblieu, ſi je ſera pendue! What a diſgrace to my family! not one of dem would own a me, if I ſhould be hanged.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Courage, mademoiſelle, the hazard is not ſo great as you imagine, then think of the reward. A thouſand pounds! Why that will enable you to return to your own country, with eclat, ſet up an equigage, and outſhine half the women in Languedoc. Why a thouſand Engliſh pounds, Fontange, twenty thouſand livres Françoiſes, is the portion of a marchioneſs there.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: But are you very ſure your honour mean a de marriage, after you carry her off? or elſe Fontange vil a have noting to ſay to it. She would no turn procurateur for any ting in de vorld; but in de honorable way, ſhe ſerve a her friend, ſans doute.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: O, fear me not, mademoiſelle.—You have the beſt ſecurity in the world, over me, my own intereſt.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: You muſt not come a to de houſe, till it is black dark; you get a ready de parſon and de coach; den leave a de reſt to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: My life and fortune both depend on the event.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: I wiſh a your honour de bon ſucceſs, vid all my heart; but you will not forget pauvre Fontange. I will have a de bond ready for your honour to ſign, when you come a to de houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: With all my heart, mademoiſelle. Would I had ſigned and ſealed with Emilia!

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Tout en bon tems—Adieu, Monſieur, adieu.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Myſelf was never ſo bothered what to do, in the courſe of my whole life. To be ſure I would be glad my maſter was married to madam Emilia, becauſe I believe he loves her. But this ſtealing her away by night has an ugly look with it.—And to have that wicked mademoiſelle get a good thouſand pound for helping to ruin the innocent creature; augh, that would vex me to the heart. I'll go directly, and conſult with my old friend and goſſip, Jimmy Kavanagh, that is in a good place here in town, and may be he would tell me what I would do; for I don't much care to betray my poor maſter, neither.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Sir HARRY WILMOT in a night-gown;

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I vow, Clarinda, this was vaſtly kind, now, and really more than I deſerve; but I declare, you are the very paragon of good-nature.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir Harry, I muſt ſay, it ſhews a moſt dove-like diſpoſition in me, to hazard my reputation, by viſiting a man who has juſt now endangered his life for another lady.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: There you are miſtaken, Clarinda; curſe me, if I either did, or would fight, for any woman in England—except yourſelf, ma belle fille.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: O, your ſervant, Sir—But what could have been your cauſe of quarrel, then? For Sir William, I think, never plays.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why, that ſame doughty knight-errant, you have named, took it into his wiſe head, that becauſe a certain fair lady had never allowed him a tête à tête, ſhe never meant to indulge herſelf, or any body elſe, with one; and upon my declaring that ſhe had done me that favour, talked in a high, ridiculous, romantic ſtrain of the lady's honour and character; and ſeemed to hint as if he ſuſpected me of a falſehood. That you'll allow was not to be endured.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: O, by no means, Sir Harry. However, I have not quite ſo much pity for you, as I had, as you were paid, I ſuppoſe, before-hand. A tête à tête with lady Frankland, was, I think, an over-payment for the ſlight ſcratch you have received. But you certainly did ill to boaſt: I could not have ſuſpected you of ſo much diſhonour, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why now, my dear Clarinda, there's the miſ-chief on't. I had nothing to boaſt of; for this ſame petite partie ended in a very abſurd propoſal on her ſide, for entering into the Platonic ſyſtem, which I poſitively refuſed. Car je n'ai pas le tems. Admired the elegant impracticability of her ladyſhip's ſeraphics, made my bow, and withdrew.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Very abſurd and ridiculous, truly! Equally ſo, on both ſides. I never could have ſuppoſed, that a man who knows the world, as well as you have a right to do, could have ſlipp'd ſuch an opportunity, ſo ſimply. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why faith, Clarinda, there is a kind of baſhful courage about thoſe modeſt dames, that is capable of putting the moſt impudent fellow in the world out of countenance; and tho' I was never in better ſpirits for an attack, ſhe talked ſo queerly of friendſhip, eſteem, honour, and ſuch ſtuff, that ſhe left me little to ſay, and leſs to do; ſo I e'en quitted the field, and marched off.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Shame of all cowards, ſay I; if your double defeat ſhould be known, you will be hooted out of the world both of love and gallantry; and faith, you deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Point de tout, ma chere fille, no man is wiſe or brave at all times, and I ſhall only ſmile at my late defeat, if I can but triumph here,

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Pſhaw, let me go; it would be ſcandalous in me to ſubmit to a beaten general—conqueſt is the road to conqueſt, both in love and war; and the illuſtrious name of our victorious leader, has been a legion added to our troops: Engliſh women, as well as men, chuſe to liſt under a brave commander.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Vaſtly ſevere and piquant, truly! but I ſhall have my repriſals, ſome other time.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: You'll have better luck than you deſerve, then. Farewel, poor recreant knight.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Adieu, ma bizarre!

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: The ſtreet before Lady Frankland's houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Love and jealouſy are twins, I find, born in the ſelf-ſame moment. What tranſports have I felt, what agonies endured, within a few ſhort hours! That angel form which bleſſed my eyes and ears this morn, e're noon transformed into a mortal object! ſurrounded by a crowd of coxcombs! By heaven, ſhe freely gave her hand to lord Mount-Faſhion, and ſuffered him to lead her from that vulgar ſcene of hurry, noiſe, and nonſenſe. I'll ſee if ſhe is returned. [Raps at the door, and enter Nicodemus] Is your lady at home, friend?

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Noa, Sir, I'ſe wiſh ſhe were, for ſervants are all well y'clemmed, and cook ſays dinner's a-ſpoiling—Madam Emilia's at home tho', if your honour pleaſes to walk in.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: No, friend, 'tis very well. [Exit Nicodemus, and ſhuts the door.] And yet I think I will go in, and wait for her.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Soa, Sir, what mun you want now?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I have changed my mind, and will go in to wait for your lady's return.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: You'ſe welcome. I'ſe ſwear you'ſe a perſon of quality, for they never know their own minds. (Aſide). Do walk in, Sir, pray.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: After the declaration you made this morning; it ſurprizes me, madam, to find you in this retired ſituation.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: One often ſays more, Sir William, as well as leſs, than they think, according to the degree of ſpirits they happen to be in. I confeſs myſelf a rattle, and have vivacity enough to be fond of public places. Yet, I very ſoon tire of them, and frequently prefer the gaiety of theſe little objects, which I can create with my pencil, and the enjoyment of my own thoughts, to the more glaring ſhadows which ſurround me abroad, and no thought at all. 'Tis vaſtly pleaſant to think ſometimes, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: They are, indeed, truly unhappy who do not find it ſo. Guilt alone can make reflection painful.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
I muſt differ with you, Sir William; for I really know many good ſort of people, who I am ſure
have nothing to reproach themſelves with, yet for want of an early habit, dread ſitting alone, as much as if they feared ſpirits, and would run into any kind of company, rather than endure their own.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Charming, ſenſible, unaffected girl (aſide). He muſt be a happy man, Emilia, who ſhall ſhare the pleaſures of retirement, with a companion lively and rational as you.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Pray do not make me vain, Sir William; perhaps no body may have it ſo much in their power as you.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: That declaration ought to make me proud, madam.—But I have been ſo charmed with your ſentiments upon retirement, that I almoſt forgot the occaſion of my intruding upon yours. Do you know any thing of lady Frankland? Does ſhe dine at home?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I have not ſeen her ſince morning, but I am ſo well acquainted with her ladyſhip's regularity and politeneſs, that I have not the leaſt doubt of her returning to dinner (looking at her watch). Bleſs me 'tis very late; I have never known her ſtay ſo long abroad.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I have ſome little buſineſs to communicate to her ladyſhip, and ſhall take the liberty of waiting on her ſoon after dinner.
sp.stage: [A noiſe of rapping at a door within.]

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: O, here ſhe comes; and as you ſay you have buſineſs, I ſhall withdraw; but pray don't detain her long, Sir William, for I am vaſtly hungry.
sp.stage: [Lady Frankland ſpeaking before ſhe comes in.]

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Will my dear Emilia excuſe me this treſpaſs on her patience? But I vow it was not poſſible for me to get away from lord Mount-Faſhion, one moment ſooner. (Enters.) Sir William, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Your's, Madam; I am ſurprized that his lordſhip could part with you, even now, Madam: I did ſuppoſe you had been gone to dine with him at lady Fanſhaw's, or ſome other of his lordſhip's fond admirers.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you, Sir William; I ſhould certainly have dined abroad, if I had happened to have one of my own ſervants with me, to have ſent home to Emilia. I did not expect the favour of your company, Sir, therefore cannot charge myſelf with any want of politeneſs toward you.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Want of politenefs, Madam! is that a term to me? whoſe heart-ſtrings you have ſtrained, and taught to feel more racking agonies, than e'er Damien knew! keep your politeneſs for your lord Mount-Faſhion, Madam; I hoped I had an higher claim.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Are theſe the ſentiments, Sir William, which gave that claim? Where is that nice reſpect, thoſe ſoft expreſſions of friendſhip and eſteem, which pleaded for that claim?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Vaniſhed, Madam! fled in the moment that you gave your hand to that ſame peregrine lord.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Deluſion all! they never yet exiſted in your breaſt; ſelf-love alone aſſumed the form of ſentimental paſſion, and has impoſed on you, but never ſhall again on me.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Cruel, unkind! vain metaphyſical diſtinction! you know I would ſacrifice a thouſand lives to pleaſe you, detach myſelf from the whole univerſe, and give up every thought to you, and you alone! Is this ſelf-love?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: True love requires no ſacrifice, but the heart; ſelf love muſt have its triumphs: ſuſpicion is its conſtant mate, and the leaſt degree of complaiſance ſhewn to another object, appears a robbery to ſelfiſh minds. In ſhort, there can be no ſlavery equal to that a jealous lover would impoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I, Madam, I render you a ſlave! you, Madam, whoſe empire is ſo abſolutely over me!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Sir William, I ſhall ever acknowledge the higheſt obligations to you; you have drawn me from the verge of a precipice, into which my own imprudence had like to have plunged me—I awake from an illuſion, and can dream no more—Be my friend ſtill, this is the only rank that you can ever hold in my regards.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Heavens, Madam! what crime have I committed, that you ſhould wiſh my death?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Far from it, Sir William; I wiſh your happineſs, ſo far as it may not be inconſiſtent with my own; and by depriving you of all right to be jealous, I lay you under the happy neceſſity of ceaſing to be ſo. I begin to dread the violence of your temper, and what we fear, we cannot love.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I begin to know you, Madam, in my turn; the refinement of a platonic paſſion, but ill agrees with the ſlightneſs of your conduct. Sir Harry Wilmot would have been a more ſuitable lover, and I was certainly wrong to interfere—

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Stop there, Sir William; I know already how much I am indebted to you, upon that occaſion; and ſhall therefore retire, to ſave you the confuſion of having reproached me with an obligation, which even this behaviour cannot cancel, nor ſhall I forget.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Diſtraction! what have I done! upbraided lady Frankland! ſhe is, ſhe muſt be irrecoverably loſt to me! But by what bond could I have hoped to hold her? Platonics, I am now convinced, are all a jeſt; and her virtue, and my own honour, both forbid all other ties.

q.l: Accurſed jealouſy! too well you prove
If for themſelves alone we ſought the fair,
Kindneſs to others would not cauſe deſpair;
But when ſelf-love begins to warp the mind,
We dread a rival in each paſſing wind.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: MY deareſt Emilia, I have now opened my whole ſoul to you. My mind is a perfect chaos; yet I feel as if a weight had been taken off my breaſt, by this moſt fortunate breach with Sir William. Oh, my Emilia, how near have I been to ruin! I am frighted even at the proſpect.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: You ſhould contemplate it rather, with that kind of pleaſure, with which they view the wreck, who have juſt eſcaped the ſtorm, with a proper ſenſe toward providence, and a ſteady purpoſe never to run the ſame riſque again.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Humbled as I now am, Emilia, ſuch reſolutions are natural, and bare remembrance of the peril I've eſcaped, muſt certainly inſure my perſeverance. But alas, my friend, have I not reaſon to accuſe my fate, for turning thoſe advantages, which are deemed a bleſſing to my ſex, into a curſe for me! youth, beauty, innocence, and ſenſibility, to what have ye reduced me! to become the ſport of foppery, or victim of jealouſy! Is this the world I have been taught to admire? For what illuſions have I ſtrayed from real happineſs, which I am now convinced is only to be found, in the calm indulgence
of rational affections. In the repoſe, rather than tumult of the ſoul.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I rejoice to find that the natural good ſenſe of my amiable friend has been only hoodwinked, but not blinded, and that ſhe can ſo clearly ſee her errors now

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Yes, wretch that I am! I ſee them but too late; after I have forfeited the friendſhip, the confidence, and regards, of the beſt of men and huſbands! thank heaven, though, that I have nothing to reproach myſelf with, except imprudence; and yet, Emilia, can I hope that Lord Frankland ſhould take my word for this, or even condeſcend to liſten to my juſtification? How I deteſt the writers of romance! Oh, Emilia, 'tis but too eaſy to ſwerve from the right path, but difficult indeed to recover it again.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Why difficult? the little deviation you have made, requires no artful clue. There are no bars againſt you, but thoſe your fears create. Lord Frankland is ſtill the ſame tender, affectionate huſband he has ever been, and gave a proof of it this morning, by requeſting you to quit all farther intimacy with Clarinda, whom he ſeems to think no ſafe companion for your honour.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Another precipice! an angel's guard has ſurely hovered over me! O were he to forbid my converſe with all the world, with light itſelf, with every thing but thee, nay, nay, even with thee, Emilia! his will ſhould be obeyed.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
My heart exults at finding yours ſo ſenſible of duty. O, Lady Frankland, you have indeed
eſcaped from many dangers yet unknown. Nor can a wife e'er find a place of ſafety, but under the protection of that heaven-appointed guard, her huſband. Loſe not a moment then, but let us fly to your aſylum—That generous man, who has ever pitied and bewailed your errors, will open wide his arms to your returning virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Alas, Emilia, a certain native pride, or rather conſcious ſhame, which generous minds alone, are capable of, reſtrains my ſteps. I muſt firſt endeavour to be reconciled to myſelf, before I can even hope for his forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Mr Ambroſe is come to wait upon your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: In a lucky minute, ſure! a thought has juſt occurred—If bleſt with ſucceſs, my dear Emilia ſhall be the firſt partaker of my joy. For the preſent, leave me. [Exit Emilia, expreſſing by her looks and geſture her joy and wiſhes.] Deſire Mr Ambroſe to walk in. [Exit Nicodemus. Now for the laſt act of expiring romance!
How does my Lord, and yours, good Ambroſe?

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: In health, may heaven be praiſed for it; I have not been ſo happy as to ſee your ladyſhip, for ſome time paſt, though I have called here daily, by my lord's command.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am obliged to his lordſhip, and to you alſo, Mr Ambroſe.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: O madam, would it were within my power to oblige your ladyſhip, your poor old ſervant would lay down his life, to ſhew his duty.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Then, Ambroſe, you have it in your power to do me a moſt eſſential ſervice.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip has but to command, and I obey. Would to heaven that my lord and you loved yourſelves, but as well as I love either of you. I know not which of you was to blame, but I am ſure my heart bleeds for you both. How it uſed to delight me, to ſee you together. It was a bleſſed ſight! and ſince your ſeparation, I have ſeen nothing but affliction in our houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I take the blame upon myſelf, good Ambroſe, yet I have hopes my fault may be repaired, if you will but implicitly follow my directions.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: Doubtleſs, madam, I ſhall obey.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You know that my picture remains ſtill in my lord's houſe.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: Ay, madam, and my lord knows it too, full well; he ſhuts himſelf up with it whole days, gazes on it, talks to it, then ſighs enough to break one's heart to hear him—'Tis all his company and conſolation, now—I dare not ſpeak. But—

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Your words pierce through my ſoul! I have not merited this kindneſs; I thought his heart inſenſible
and cold, dead to all tenderneſs for me; but let his generous foftneſs quicken mine. Ambroſe, you muſt ſteal that picture for me, and bring it hither this very inſtant, unſeen by mortal eye.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: What, madam! rob my maſter of his only treaſure! Bid me lay down my life, and I'll obey.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Be aſſured I do not mean to deprive him of it. This evening you ſhall replace it in my huſband's chamber. My ſole requeſt is that you will not let him know it has been moved. You can't refuſe me, ſure!

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip is goodneſs itſelf, and I can't ſuppoſe you would put an end to my life, by the grief it would give me to afflict, or offend the beſt of maſters—I will then inſtantly obey your ladyſhip's commands—But pray, good lady, remember that it muſt be reſtored, this very evening.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You may rely upon my promiſe, indeed, good Ambroſe— [Exit] Ambroſe. To hymen's ſacred power, though late, an ardent votary I bend—Oh! may he proſper, and aſſiſt my purpoſe!

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: An apartment in Lady FANSHAW's houſe.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
I can't tell you how much I am diſappointed at the folly of that coxcomb, Sir Harry—I had great hopes that his ſpirited aſſurance might have conquered her timid baſhfulneſs; and a breach once
made in that baſtion, the citadel falls of courſe. I begin to fear ſhe'll conterwork us all, and either keep the fortreſs in her own hands, or perhaps deliver it back again to the former governor, in ſtatu quo.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I can't agree with you, Clarinda, though even Sir Harry has failed. For I dare ſwear no woman ever parted from her huſband, with a deſign of playing the drude with all the reſt of the world. I fancy now, that Sir William will carry the town—not by ſtorm indeed, but by ſtarving the beſieged into terms of capitulation.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I don't underſtand your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Why then, in plainer Engliſh, Sir William is grown jealous, and will, if poſſible, prevent any other man from coming near her. By this means, ſhe will find herſelf priſoner, and may then probably ſurrender her perſon, to obtain her liberty, en parole, at leaſt.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: You deal ſtill in tropes, Lady Fanſhaw.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Ay, but you underſtand me, for all that, Clarinda. You know full well that when a woman puts herſelf into the power of a man, he becomes a tyrant, ſhe a ſlave, from that moment; and all the difference I can find, between marriage and gallantry, is, that one is perpetual, the other temporary, only.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
I care not by what means her ruin is accompliſhed, provided it be accompliſhed. Her fatal marriage with Lord Frankland, blaſted all my
hopes, and I cannot bear to think that ſhe ſhould taſte the heart-felt joy of her own virtue, while I am deprived of that, as well as of what I reſigned it for.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Nay, as to that Clarinda, it is no ſuch mighty matter, that one need wiſh to rob her of it, for we both know with regard to the world, the appearance will anſwer, as well as the reality. But if you are bent upon her ruin, blaſt her reputation, my dear—The ſtory you told me of the duel, properly managed, is ſufficient to do that effectually.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: That alone ſhall deſtroy her fame, ſhould ſhe even preſerve her chaſtity, which you ſeem to think improbable.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I have half a ſcore viſits to make to morrow morning and I ſhall take care to whiſper this adventure in every one of them, with the tendereſt profeſſions of pity for her misfortune, and a who could have ſuſpected it? I vow I thought her perfectly innocent, but I am afraid lord Frankland had his reaſons—though he had too much pride to publiſh them,

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: This will do, my dear Lady Fanſhaw; for let women value themſelves ever ſo much upon their innocence, the loſs of character is next to that of virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: O much worſe, Clarinda—But I muſt go and viſit that ſimple Sir Harry, as he is confined; I own I deſpiſe him, but to perſons of certain ranks in life, one muſt be civil, you know.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I ſhall ſend to know if Lady Frankland be at home. If ſhe is, I'll pay her a viſit; perhaps Sir William may be there, and I may poſſibly diſcover ſomething to corroborate our ſtory. But that ſilly chit Emilia never leaves her, ſo that the woman wants opportunity, were ſhe ever ſo well inclined—I wiſh that girl was any how out of the way.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: She'll marry Charles Frankland, and be a wretch.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: You have told me a moſt extraordinary ſtory, James; are you ſure your countryman's veracity may be depended upon.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Pleaſe your honour, I have known him from a child, and never had cauſe to doubt it—He is ſimply honeſt.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Then ſure his maſter is an horrid villain! bid your friend attend me in my ſtudy—I muſt have all the particulars from himſelf. [Exit ſervant.] Can it be poſſible there lives a wretch ſo vile, to form a ſcheme for violating helpleſs innocence, and ſpoiling blooming beauty! my fair, my ſenſible Emilia, I will protect thee, at the hazard of my life; ſurely ſhe holds a place within my breaſt, its feelings are too ſtrong for friendſhip's power; her danger has awakened all my tenderneſs, endeared her to my ſoul, and made me know eſteem to be the ſureſt baſe for love.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: The ſtreet before Lady FRANKLAND's houſe.

Enter a footman, with a card in his hand; as he is ſtaring about for the houſe, Mr Frankland comes ſoftly down the ſide of the ſtage, muffled in a cloak. Fontange opens the door, looks about, and lets him in.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: That was as nicely done now as if I had a hand in it, myſelf. High preſto, paſs and be gone—as the conjurer ſays. That muſt be the houſe, for I ſaw my lady's ugly Frenchwoman open the door—Aye, aye, I am right.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: So Nic.—How do'ſt do, my lad? Is your Lady at home?

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Why aye—I think ſo.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: There, carry that card to her then, from my lady madam Clarinda, and bring me an anſwer, ſtraight.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Nic. has a rare place of it, ſurely—Such a fine handſome woman as his miſtreſs, muſt have a deal of rich gallants come after her—And ſhe is not cruel, I find.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: My lady will write an anſwer, directly, and you mun ſtay to carry it, for iſe get going enough.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: You're a lucky rogue, Nic, to get into ſuch a ſervice; to have ſo beautiful a young lady your miſtreſs—I warrant me you'll be for purchaſing into the funds, by and by.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Funds! I believe you'ſe making fun of me—Why mon, ſince thoſe curſed ſociations for dropping of vails, have been in faſhion, a poor ſarvant can ſcarce keep himſelf whole and clean. Funds quotha!

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: Why really, as you ſay, ſince the incroachment upon our perquiſites, it is not worth any man of ſpirit's while to wear a livery, except where there is a little private buſineſs going forward—You underſtand me; and in that caſe, we muſt be touched handſomely, for huſh-money, you know. I'll warrant now, you make above forty pounds a year of your lady.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Not I, as I hope to be ſaved—She gives me but the bare ten guineas, and I have hardly any requiſites at all; for my lady don't love play.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: Don't ſhe, really?
sp.stage: [Bell rings—Nic. goes out, and returns with a letter]

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Here's my lady's anſwer

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: Good by to you, friend Nic. Since you're ſo plaguy dry.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: That indeed, I am always—And ſhould be glad to take a pot of beer with you, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: Another time may ſerve, good Mr Sly-boots.
sp.stage: SCENE draws, and diſcovers FONTANGE leading in Mr. FKANKLAND.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, I am all in a fluſter, I tremble from head to foot. If you do not ſucceed, that madame Clarinda's ſerviteur diſcovery me—He ſaw me at de door—O, de bonté, monſieur, what vill become of me, if ſhe be not very, very quiet?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Why faith, mademoiſelle, I find myſelf a little diſconcerted too, at preſent, and have a foreboding ſufficient to deter another man from the attempt, but I am determined to proceed, in ſpite of qualms, either of my conſcience, or her virtue—This night puts an end to my life, or my misfortunes. I come prepared you ſee.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: O de bonne grace! you terrify me out of my life—Why, monſieur, if you ſhould ſhoot a yourſelf, the king he get a your fortune—I never can recover my bond, againſt your heirs.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You need not be in pain upon that account, mademoiſelle, for if I ſhould be taken off this moment, by an apoplexy, I ſhould die my own executor.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Helas! den, I have venture my neck for noting, I have de great mind to go and diſcover de whole affair this very minute, ſince I find I am no to be paid.

sp.speaker: FRANKLAND.
sp.p: If you attempt to ſqueak, I ſhall ſilence you. Madame.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Pardonnez moi, monſieur, take away de piſtol, and I vill no ſqueaka—But do, pray ſign a de bond, if it be only for de ſatisfaction to my own conſcience, that I did no commit a de ſin, for noting.

sp.speaker: FRANKLAND.
sp.p: There, mademoiſelle, and may you be intitled to your reward, with all my heart. It is not witneſſed, therefore not valid.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Je vous rend mille, grace, monſieur—The bell ring, get into that cloſet; de key is in de inſide—Be ſure you no ſtir, till all de houſe be in de bed.

sp.speaker: FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Doubt not my diſcretion.
sp.stage: [He goes into the cloſet, and exit mademoiſelle.]

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: An apartment in Lady FANSHAW's houſe.
Lady FANSHAW and CLARINDA diſcovered at cards.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: You are repiqued, Clarinda.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Well, that makes us even. I wiſh Thomas was returned.
sp.stage: Enter BETTY, and delivers a letter to CLARINDA.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: From Lady Frankland, ma'm,

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
To me! what can it mean? [Opens and reads] Lady Frankland's and Emilia's compliments to Clarinda, and requeſt ſhe will not give herſelf
the trouble of coming any more to Lady Frankland's houſe, as they are under a neceſſity of declining her viſits, for reaſons not proper to be explained.—Forbid the houſe! this is aſtoniſhing!

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: It would almoſt tempt one to think they had a familiar, who could diſcover your heart to them.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: For that matter, I believe one of them is familiar enough—with the gentlemen, at leaſt; if what Thomas ſays be true.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Why really, Betty, gentlemen are the moſt agreeable familiars a lady can have.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Very true, to be ſure, my lady; but too much familiarity breeds content, as the proverb ſays; and I never ſhould have thought of repeating what Thomas told me, the longeſt day I have to live, if it was not for their hypocriſy in refuſing the viſits of ſuch a ſweet virtuous lady as my miſtreſs, that I have known, as it were, from a child. But ſome folks have fair faces, and foul hearts, in troth.—

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: They had better have ſhut other people's doors againſt me, than their own; for henceforth, where I enter, they never more ſhall be received—I'll blaſt that little prudiſh minx Emilia, too; I'll ſay any thing of them both that revenge can inſtigate.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Upon my verily, ma'm, I cannot bear to ſee you ſo inſtigationed by ſlights and malice, when if you knew but all, you need not be beholding to inventions, in the leaſt, ma'm; for as ſure as day, and as I hope to be ſaved, ma'm, Thomas ſaw a man
muffled up in a diſguiſe, let in juſt n • w, to Lady Frankland's houſe, by her mademaſelle there, who to be ſure and ſartin is like the reſt of her countrywomen, no better than ſhe ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Ha, Clarinda! this is a lucky diſcovery for you.—I find her grave ladyſhip has not conſined her ſtudies intirely to romance, but has dipt a little into the more practical buſineſs of novel too, and ſeems to be a pretty apt ſcholar, for her time, truly.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: This ſecret is worth a million—who could he be?

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: It muſt certainly be the ſly Sir William.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: No matter who—She is now in my power, and I will uſe the advantage—This very inſtant I will write to Lord Frankland, he may command admittance, though I am denied, for reaſons not proper to be explained, and will, I hope, find reaſon to be convinced that her affected delicacy is as eaſily conquered, as the natural openneſs of my too generous heart.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I am ſure it would be a burning ſin, and ſhame too, not to detract, and ruinate ſuch vild hypocrite creatures, for a couple of ſlippery heels, as they are.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I am of opinion, Clarinda, that your information will have but little weight with Lord Frankland, as you may be ſuppoſed to have ſome intereſt in the diſcovery.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, madam, he has the quickeſt ſenſe of honour, and will fly, either to convict or acquit her—Bid Thomas be in the way to carry my Letter. [Exit Betty. What a triumph will be mine! this night I ſhall expoſe, and laugh to ſcorn the ſaint-like Lady Frankland, tear off the veil ſhe has ſo long aſſumed, and ſhew her genuine features to the world.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Well, come my dear, do give vent to your refentment—or it may hurt you mightily.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Lady FRANKLAND's picture deprived of all its ornaments, the hair diſhevelled, tears ſtreaming from the eyes, and the hands in a ſupplicating poſture.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am uneaſy, till I know from Emilia, whether my wife has broke off her intercouſe with Clarinda.—Why ſhould I doubt it? ſhe never yet oppoſed my will, her temper's eaſy as her air; calm, placid, and ſerene, as that fair ſemblance.

Ha! what enchantment's this! that countenance, no longer placid and ſerene, ſpeaks agonizing woe! the hair diſhevelled too! the hands held up in ſupplication! can it be to me! tears ſtreaming from the eyes, the precious drops, perhaps, of penitence and love! amazement all! Who waits?
Ambroſe, look there! explain this wonder to my aſtoniſhed ſenſe, while I have reaſon left to comprehend you. How came that picture thus?

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: My deareſt lord, upon my bended knees I beg forgiveneſs; but could you have ſeen with what an earneſt fondneſs and deſire ſhe urged me to this deed, you would yourſelf have granted her requeſt—How then could I refuſe!

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Do not torture me! but ſay, with brevity, and truth, who urged you to this deed?

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: O! moderate the ſtrong emotions of your mind, and I will tell you all. It was my lady Frankland, your lordſhip's fond, repentant, faithful wife—But if the crime be paſt forgiveneſs, O let your anger fall on me; even drive me from your ſight, which of all puniſhments would be the ſaddeſt to me, but forgive my lady.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Riſe, Ambroſe, riſe, and ſhare your maſter's joy, which thus runs o'er. [Wiping his eyes, and gazing at the picture.] It muſt be ſo—It was her former, 'tis her preſent image. Quick let me fly then, to this fair tranſformed, kiſs off the pearly drops from her pale cheek, and dry them with the warmeſt ſighs of love; claſp thoſe imploring hands, and preſs that heaving boſom to my heart.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: May heaven be praiſed for this moſt bleſt event! I ſhall ſee my deareſt lord and lady happy once more, and then I've lived enough.
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Lady FRANKLAND's dreſſing room, ſhe ſitting leaning on her arm, the ornaments of her head taken off.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: With what impatience have I told the minutes, ſince I deemed it poſſible Lord Frankland might have ſeen the picture! Ambroſe, perhaps, deceived me. He may not look upon it, or if he ſhould, how am I ſure that he will turn his eyes on me? But ſhould he even deſpiſe my ſorrows, and leave me to my fate, I ought not to complain! But 'tis impoſſible—I know his generous heart will melt at my diſtreſs. At leaſt, he ſure will pity and forgive!
sp.stage: Enter Lord FRANKLAND, and ſtands at the ſide of the ſcene, gazing at her.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: My bounding heart ſprings from my breaſt, to meet her—How beautiful ſhe looks! and Oh! how exquiſite thoſe charms, which even the veil of ſorrow cannot ſhade!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Heavens!
sp.stage: [Looking at him, and falling back in her chair.]

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Is then the deareſt, faireſt of her ſex, again reſtored to the fond heart and arms, of her adoring huſband!
sp.stage: [Runs to catch her in his arms and embrances her.]

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Oh! if not held unworthy of that bleſſing, her wiſhes are complete.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Unworthy, ſaid you! you never were, nor could be ſo; through all the winding maze of gaiety and youth, my eyes have followed ſtill their darling object; nor has my heart one moment ceaſed to love, to pity, and eſteem you. Had the charms of pleaſure, or the ſnares of vice, infatuated your heart, that heart would ne'er have ſighed to turn
again to me. When I was firſt flattered at receiving the poſſeſſion of it with that fair hand, I claimed it as an huſband's right—I now accept it as a generous gift, and ſet the higher value on the prize.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Alas, my lord, your tenderneſs and generoſity overpower me—They are indeed much more than I deſerve, yet, though bluſhing for my follies, let me ſay no crime has rendered me unworthy of your goodneſs—My heart is free from ſtain, and henceforth I may hope thy image there, ſhall ſhield it from all future weakneſs.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Can you ſuppoſe I doubt it, while with tranſports ſuch as thoſe, I claſp it to my own.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: My dear Lady Erankland, joy, like mine, is not to be reſtrained by common forms—Lucy this moment told me ſhe ſaw Lord Frankland come into your dreſſing room, and though perhaps, I interrupt your happineſs, I muſt indulge my own, by wiſhing to you both, that true felicity which I well know you both deſerve.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: The generous friend who has ſhared the ſorrows of my heart, has a right ſurely to partake its joys; and if my preſent happineſs could admit addition, it muſt be found in that which my Emilia feels.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I know of nought that could increaſe my bliſs, but ſeeing you rejoice, Emilia.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Madam, Sir William Belville is below, and begs to ſpeak with you immediately; he ſays the cauſe of his intruſion at ſo late an hour, will be a ſufficient apology for it. There is a ſervant of Mr Frankland's, Patrick, madam, who ſays he has been at Lord Frankland's with a letter for him, but his lordſhip was not at home.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: They were miſtaken, Lucy, for this is now my home.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: What ſhall I do, Lady Frankland?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: See him, by all means, Emilia. There muſt be ſome uncommon cauſe for ſuch an ill-timed viſit.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Deſire him to walk in here, Lucy, every mark of politeneſs, is due to his character.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: What buſineſs Mr Frankland's ſervant can have with Sir William, or with me, I can not imagine.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: A little time will explain this myſtery, Emilia.
sp.stage: Enter Sir WILLIAM, PATRICK, and LUCY.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
I am extremely happy at finding your Lordſhip here, as I am perſuaded this meeting muſt render Lady Frankland and you ſo; and as the affair which brings me hither, concerns the honour of
your lordſhip's Family. For which reaſon I meant to have waited on you at your houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Sir William I am very glad to ſee you, upon any occaſion, but I think I have as little to fear, on the account you mention, as any man, for I happen not to be bleſt with any female relations, but thoſe ladies who now ſtand before you.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, you may indeed boaſt your having nothing to be alarmed at from feminine connections; for if virtue and innocence were to become embodied, and chuſe their forms, they would be thoſe of Lady Frankland and Emilia—But your lordſhip has, I think, a male relation, counſellor Frankland.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Augh, that's my maſter, now, and faith myſelf is almoſt ſorry I expoſed him before ſuch great company.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: What of him, Sir William? I look upon him as a very honeſt, ſenſible, and ſober young man, rather too grave for one of his age.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Augh hone, how little he knows of him?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I fear then you are deceived, my lord—This honeſt ſimple fellow here, his own ſervant, this morning overheard a ſcheme laid between him and Fontange, Lady Frankland's woman, for no leſs than the abſolute ruin of this lady.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Heavens! how I tremble!

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am unwilling to think ſo vilely of human nature, in any inſtance, and much more ſo of Charles Frankland, in particular, as to ſuppoſe this to be true. What proof can you produce, friend, that ſuch a villainy was e'er intended?

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Upon my ſafe conſcience, my lord, my own two ears heard them talk about it, in my maſter's chambers; and that ugly jade, that madame Fontange, was to get a good thouſand pounds for aſſiſting him in carrying her off.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I cannot be perſuaded that Charles is ſuch a villain!

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Why, my lord, if he is not in the houſe this very inſtant, why then Patrick's a lyar, and never believe him more, Augh-hone! myſelf is ſorry enough for his doing ſuch a bad thing, and it would break my heart to ſee him go to Tyburn for it, among a parcel of dirty, black-guard highwaymen, that would loſe their life for five or ſix guineas, and not among gentlemen, like himſelf, that would be hanged for killing their friend in a fair quarrel, or running handſomely away with their miſtreſs. But upon my own ſoul, though, it would be a thouſand pities to ruin that ſweet creture, for all that.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
If Charles be found in the houſe, Emilia, I fear the reſt of the ſtory is then too true. Yet as the crime has not been perpetrated, I would wiſh to ſave him both from the ſhame, as well as the
puniſhment he deſerves. I will go ſearch, and bring him from his hold.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I requeſt your lordſhip will allow me, and this honeſt fellow, to attend you, if it be only to approve our truth.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: By no means, Sir William, your honour has been proved ſufficiently, in the detection. His ſervants honeſty ſhall be rewarded.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Great luck to your lordſhip.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: How is it poſſible, Sir William, to repay this ſervice?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I ſhall ever conſider it as the greateſt happineſs of my life, that it has been in my power to render you any, madam; and if it might not appear to be preſuming too much upon the preſent incident, I ſhould intreat you to accept all the future ſervices of my life. I rejoice to find your ladyſhip has led the way into the only path to real happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I have not the leaſt doubt of your generoſity, Sir William, and ſhall ever be ready, with true gratitude, to own my obligations.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: If your ladyſhip thinks you have any, 'tis in your power to overpay them now, by joining me to requeſt the fair Emilia to accept my hand and heart. Both your ladyſhip and I have ſeen the error of imagining they can be ſeparated.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND,
sp.p: I allow it, Sir William, and as I know no perſon ſo capable of rendering my Emilia happy, I entreat—

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: My dear lady Frankland, I will not make a merit of granting that to your requeſt, which I think Sir William's own deſerts have a right to claim.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: The generous manner of conferring, would, if poſſible, double the obligation.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I have ſecured the poor unhappy wretch to ſave him from himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Then it was true, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Too true, Sir; I made his vile accomplice, trembling and ſcared, convey me to the place where he lay concealed; but when he ſaw me ſtand before him, guilt and confuſion flaſhed into his face—He thought it was an apparition, and ſtiffened quite with horror. I cloſed upon him inſtantly, and ſeized the piſtols which lay by his ſide. He then fell on his knees, confeſſed his crime, and begged that I would give him from my hand, that death which he deſerved.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I grieve to think, my lord, this happy hour ſhould have been interrupted by ſuch a ſad event.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: 'Tis rather ſure an addition to my bliſs, that you are ſaved from miſery, Emilia—But to Sir William Belville, your firſt and greateſt thanks are due.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: If he is not ſatisfied with my payments, my lord, he muſt e'en take out a ſtatute of bankruptcy againſt me, for I have already ſurrendered to him every thing I was miſtreſs of.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Then I give him joy, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: As for you, honeſt Patrick, I think the leaſt return I can make you, for ſaving my life and honour, is to preſent you with the ſame ſum that Fontange was to have had for deſtroying both.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs and proſper your ladyſhip, for that. Patrick will carry it into his own country, and that itſelf would be a help to poor Ireland, for every one has a pluck at it, and would be glad to take all they can get from it, and no body never gives it nothing at all.
sp.stage: Enter NICODEMUS, with a letter to Lord FRANKLAND.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: One of your ſervants has juſt brought this from your lordſhip's houſe, he ſays the man who gave it him, bid him carry it where-ever you were, if he ſhould not meet with your honour at home.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Have I permiſſion?
sp.stage: [They all bow, and he opens the letter; and looks at the bottom.
sp.p:
From Clarinda! [reads the letter] Malicious woman! Oh! let the venomed ſhaft with which ſhe meant to wound my tendereſt part, now lodge in her own breaſt. [Aſide.] [Gives the letter to Lady Frankland.
You ſee, my dear, I had ſufficient cauſe to warn you againſt this dangerous woman; and I am pleaſed to find that her reſentment has ariſen from your kind attention to my deſire in forbidding her your houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: This fortunate deliverance, with every other ſucceſsful event of my future life, may add to my happineſs, but cannot increaſe that love and gratitude, with which my heart o'erflows to thee its generous protector, and its ſureſt guide.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Pleaſe your ladyſhip, mademoiſelle has got out of the window of the room where his lordſhip left her, thoa I'ſe have the key ſafe enough in my pocket—Shall I go after, and lug her back?

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: No, let the wretch eſcape; the diſappointment of her avarice, be the puniſhment of her crime; but henceforth I intreat my deareſt wife will never employ foreigners again, while there are perſons in our own country, both in trade and ſervice, ſufficient to ſupply our uſes.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: In this, and every thing elſe, my pride and pleaſure ſhall be, to obey my deareſt lord.
sp.l: Too plainly have I prov'd, that unconfin'd,
Our little ſkiff is toſs'd by every wind,
On rocks and quickſands often is it caſt,
And frequent ſunk by cruel ſlander's blaſt;
But when our pilot at the helm appears,
With ſteady hand and compaſs when he ſteers.
In full ſecurity we ſail with eaſe,
And fear nor driving winds, nor raging ſeas.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Clive, with an EPILOGUE in her Hand.

lg.l: OH! I am ſick with laughing—almoſt dead!
Well! ſure, of all the epilogues I ever read,
This is the dulleſt! ah! that head! that head!
Such flimſy, poor, quaint traſh, was never penn'd!
And what's ſtill worſe, he ſtiles himſelf a friend.
I wiſh he'd be his own, and ceaſe to write,
I vow the Chriſtmas bell-man beats him quite.
Such ſtuff is only fit for Recitative,
Let's ſee—I'll try a ſtave or two—your leave—
"To you, ye brave, and alſo you, ye fair!
"Our female author does her fears declare—
"Invokes your pity—pleads her firſt offence,
"And that 'tis merit, ev'n to make pretence."
Ding! dong!
I'll write an air, myſelf, to't—then you'll roar
Bravo! braviſſimo! divine! encore!
But hold—Piano, gentlefolks—For here
I'm running on, without all ſenſe of fear—
What's this to'th' play? (puts up the paper) our author, there ſhe ſits!
As I'm alive, ſhe's going into fits!
Our female bard—the writer of this play—
Dear me! what is't that I was go'ng to ſay?
Lord, I'm ſo flounder'd! ſo confuſed!—No ſcheme
To bring me off!—I'll tell you an odd dream—
Not mine—t'was hers—So I'll juſt give you a hint,
And leave you to infer what meaning's in't.
Our Sappho took a nap—you'll ſay you know it;
Is that uncommon in a modern poet?
But let that paſs—When borne on fancy's wing,
To the ſmoth brink of the Caſtalian ſpring,
She quaff'd ſo large a draught, it turned her brain
As mad—as ſome of you are with champaign—
Straight ſhe began to rave 'bout inſpiration!
Plot—diction—moral—ſentiment—and paſſion.
Then ſcrambling up Parnaſſus' mount, ſhe ſpied
The fiery Pegaſus—and vow'd ſhe'd ride.
Now I've been told, d'ye ſee, that this ſame ſteed,
Skittiſh, and fleet as your Newmarket breed,
Has dev'liſh pranks—and none but men can ride him,
How aukard muſt our petticoats beſtride him
'Faith, ſo it prov'd!
For as ſhe, one foot in, and one foot out,
Was tittuping her hobby-horſe about,
He gave a ſudden friſk, reared up in th' air
And canted Sappho off—among ye there!
O dire prognoſtic of her preſent ſtate!
I almoſt tremble to inquire her fate!
Explain this dream—O be our Art'midorus!
Expound by contraries, the doom before us!
Shall ſhe remount? ſhe'll bring him to his paces,
And ſhew you mettled ſport, at future races?
But metaphor apart—This I dare ſay,
On the behalf of this probation play,
Y'are bound t'encourage it—I'll tell you why—
Wit, like proviſion, now is ris'n ſo high,
That • ome expedient we muſt fall upon,
To keep the market ſtock'd, or we're undone:
Now to aboliſh all monopoly,
And furniſh out a choice, and full ſupply,
Take the advantage of a late decree,
Make't legal to import a quantity,
Of Iriſh wit—like butter—duty-free.
